I'm happy to see this finally make its debut on Steam (after a year of Epic Games exclusivity)! As a newbie to the Pinball scene, I'd say this is a nice entry. You get a few free tables to start with and then can purchase more tables as DLC; this business model of free game + DLCs makes sense as I doubt they could encase every licensed DLC within a single (reasonable) price, and still make it profitable.

The big elephant in the room is that previously, players could transfer their DLCs from Pinball FX2 to Pinball FX3 for free, as those two games ran on the same engine, and thus, there was basically no labour involved to move assets from one entry to another. The problem here is that this title makes the jump to the Unreal Engine, and thus, porting the older tables to this newer game required the devs to do manual work. As such, they're now charging again for these tables, whereas loyal fans are conditioned to expect to be able to transfer their previously purchased tables for free, as they have been able to before. This isn't a problem for new players, but again, fans who have purchased tables before are disappointed.

As an outsider looking in, I can understand the frustration; it can be debated whether the graphics were even improved, and thus, whether it worth jumping to a new engine or not in the first place. People don't want to pay for what's essentially same thing twice. On the other hand, I've seen multiple players act as though they MUST purchase the new DLCs. It's not like you're losing access to the tables you purchased 5+ years ago, those are still accessible in the phenomenal Pinball FX3, thankfully. I think expecting DLCs to be transferable isn't necessarily the norm in the gaming industry, so it's unfortunate that Zen Studios have put themselves in this situation where it's expected of them now. The DLC bundles that offer a discount for those who already own the tables from older games are a nice middle-ground, but not one everyone is satisfied with. I'm not sure what an alternative could be.

I also think the optimization / performance of this game is a bit questionable. I have to play on lowest settings at 720p to reach 60 FPS on my Steam Deck, which is a bit of a bummer. Perhaps this can be ironed out down the line via updates.

As for the game itself, it's Pinball! Lots of tables to checkout, with flashy effects and addictive sound design. I think if you're a newcomer, you'll really enjoy this game (provided you're willing to purchase / rent tables), but if you're a long-time fan, you may only have interest in this game's exclusive tables, and otherwise, you'll likely want to stick to FX3. If previous DLCs were transferable, I'm sure this game would have a much better review score. That's the biggest contention point.
Playable on Steam Deck using GE-Proton7-55 and 1280 x 800 resolution.

Plantera 2: Golden Acorn is a sequel to the popular farming and idle game, Plantera. It is a relaxing and engaging game where you grow and manage your own garden. The game has colorful and detailed graphics, pleasant music, and simple controls, making it easy to pick up and play.

In this game, your main objective is to collect Golden Acorns that come from the oak tree. These acorns can be used to unlock new features and upgrades. You start with a small garden and gradually expand it by planting various crops and trees and placing decorations. As you progress, you'll encounter different types of crops and animals, each with their own unique characteristics and requirements.

The game also features unwelcome guests like moles, crows, rabbits, and even a UFO, which can eat your crops or dig up your garden, causing damage and reducing your Golden Acorn production. However, you can protect your garden by clicking on them, hiring guard dogs, bees, and scarecrows to chase them away.

Plantera 2: Golden Acorn is a well-designed and enjoyable idle game that provides a relaxing experience. With its fun and engaging gameplay, the ability to expand your garden, and protect it from unwelcome guests, the game is definitely worth playing. Whether you're a fan of idle games or just looking for a fun and relaxing game to play, Plantera 2: Golden Acorn is a great choice.
Great graphics and music! Simple to pick up, play, and get into a groove.

The game introduces multiple concepts / resources / yet-to-be-unlocked features and then abruptly ends 4 hours in, never having capitalized on promised features. The entire game played like a demo or a tutorial.

This review was written by someone who is somewhat into many game genres, though not very relevant to this genre. I would like to list the important parts that I see in the game without any distinction between positives and negatives. (So ​​you can decide for yourself <3)

- I want to start with the gameplay time. I'm playing the game incredibly slow in a really chill mode. That's why I haven't seen every card and event in the game even though it's been over 8 hours. Therefore, based on the comments made to see all the cards, we can say that it has a gameplay of 8-10 hours. (For the early access version. And this period will be extended with new cards and events to come as long as it stays in early access.)

- Our goal in the game is to create a city based on random cards from our deck. And while doing so, it's important to keep your citizens happy. At this point, we come to the importance of balance. A difficult objective card (the red ones) at the beginning of the game can make your game really difficult as the cards come randomly. But since we depend on a few conditions to lose the game, we can say that the structure is balanced at this point. (At the beginning level of the game, the objective cards can be very difficult. But as you continue playing in a short time, the bonuses gained make this difficulty more bearable.)

- There are troubles, disasters and festivals as random events in the game. Since these are subject to a certain condition, we can slow down or speed up their arrival. I think these random events are enough for the early access phase and add excitement to the game. For example, we can lose our important buildings in case of an earthquake, or we can turn all the cards we draw into road cards with a new feature. (Come on, who likes a leader who doesn't make some road?)

- The map size did not satisfy me. In fact, the game needs to have a more appropriately sized map than it currently has. A map that is too small will not be large enough to accommodate game content. On the other hand, a very large map may show less content than it actually is. I think this needs improvement.

- I think that the small cosmetics on the table other than our game board are enough for now. Definitely an in-game currency and store should come. Or, if additional packages are to be made for the game, such cosmetics should be added to them. (But these will definitely be reserved for the full version of the game and will have no effect on gameplay.)

- Thank you for taking time to read my review. I hope this helped you to get a little idea about the game. Have fun in your Cardboard Town my friend <3

Where do I start with [i]EIGTBOK[/i]?

I first played the game on Itch several years ago-- it's been long enough now that I truly can't remember how I originally found it. I could've just been looking for new and unique indie games. Boy, did I get my wish.

A little context here, since people read reviews to see if they'll like something or not: [i]EIGTBOK[/i] is a fantastic collection of bizarre and engaging little minigames and hidden secrets on the world's weirdest desktop, but it's also what many would weightily appellate an "Art Game™", so if you get cold feet about an author being frank and open about their life or your adventures through multicolor cyberspace occasionally being interrupted by grim reminders of the real world, go now or forever hold your peace.

There, that's your tl;dr.

Still here? Good. I like you.

[i]Everything is going to be OK[/i] is not just a game about the Internet, or trauma, or the stress of being an artist. It is a stupendous crescendo to the author's previous works in the vein of web art, spanning everywhere from [i]BlueSuburbia[/i] (waiting with baited breath for that remake...) to [i]Tetrageddon[/i], and far predating pale imitators like Hypnospace Outlaw and the endless parade of other Weird Desktop Simulators we've seen in more recent years. It is the work of someone who is truly in love with their medium of choice. Nothing included is there to snag a merch deal with Hot Topic or turn into a popular Twitter meme, it's all painfully genuine, even and especially the silliest bits. 

It almost feels a little too intimate at times-- wading through the cheerfully suicidal bunnies and whimsically creaking cyberbones, it feels a bit like peaking into someone's very old and very weathered diary, new sheaves of paper shoved in every few years or so to extend its life, and consequentially expand your view of the feelings and events described within. It's fitting that so much of the more hidden content in the game is literal poetry.

Every playthrough I try to go through the little ritual of wading through the numbered programs in "order" (Numbered 'Pages', then 'missing' pages), but it's inevitable that anyone would get lost on the labyrinth somewhere along the way. This is what I would consider a feature, not a bug. Further down the line, several applications you find seem to be re-purposed or reinvigorated Alienmelon projects from days of yore, frankensteined back to life here for your enjoyment. Contest entries, desktop pets, other programs of obscure origin and even vaguer purpose. It is, and I mean this as high praise, a shockingly dense text for a solo project.

Replaying it for this review, I even found new things I somehow hadn't stumbled across before-- I'm STILL not sure how many sound effects are in the duckmonkey music minigame, for example. I can't imagine how long that must've taken to record and program. And towards the end I discovered an entire essay, hiding away in one small button. (No, I won't tell you where. That's for YOU to figure out!)

Everything Is Going To Be OK has made me cackle like a madman. It has made me contemplate my own life and the choices I've made. It has made me cry like a child. But, most pertinently to the point I am trying to make, again and again it restores my faith in video games as an art and storytelling medium. Maybe everything really [i]is[/i] going to be okay.

...Also, like, it's been in the MoMA. If that sweetens the pot for you at all.



(P.S.: My personal favorite is page 10. Little wormy was SO right about everything.)

Incredible game but will take some time to fully grasp and has some places to improve. But it is Early Access so I’m looking forward to see how this game progresses!

Some things to note:

The tutorial is serviceable, it teaches you the movement controls and combat controls well enough, but it’ll take you some time to get used to unless you’ve played other games with similar space mechanics like Space Engineers or Hardspace: Shipbreaker. Something I feel it lacks is letting you know about how interactive the maps are. Until I bumped into something with a button prompt, I had no idea I could open/close airlocks, pressurize sections, or ride cables. The tutorial should’ve at least had an example of this because it is really cool.

The class customization and the classes themselves lend to a lot of variety but there are some classes that tend to be more popular than others. Some special ordinances are clearly better than others and I can see some balancing rework being needed for some.

The actual combat is just downright awesome and it really is a tactical space shooter. 3D tactics feels both empowering and threatening as flanking maneuvers are so much more dynamic. Combat is intense and the map design blends close quarters combat with large open combat very well.

Speaking of map design. They’re some of the best I’ve seen. They are molded perfectly to their respective game modes. The only problem I could see is sometimes spawn locations can drop you in right on top of the enemy if they’re at your spawn. I didn’t suffer any spawn camping but I can definitely see it happening.

I saw other reviews talking about bugs or bad connection, and they very well may have experienced that, but I didn’t experience any kind of problems like that. My game kept up good connection, consistent frame rate, no graphical errors, or anything.

Overall I highly recommend it and look forward to seeing this game grow. I hope it gets the love and recognition it deserves. Hope to see you out there!

[h1] IGNORE THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS! [/h1]

If you have any experience at Roguelike Deckbuilders you will enjoy the game just fine. 

People whining that the game is difficult and unbalanced just don't know how to adapt to the challenge thrown at them. For reference, I finished a run on my 2nd attempt without any meta progress unlocks. While i understand people are frustrated because they have a tough time making progress, this doesn't warrant a negative review, otherwise all Souls-like games would be downvoted to oblivion. 

Some enemy decks will counter what you are building and the fight may be tough, but not unwinnable. I disagree on so many exaggerated claims made by various reviews that i wonder why they are playing a game from this genre in the first place.

I've followed the game since its first anouncement on the Nintendo Direct a year ago. I've played demo for hours and hours and it's a blast to finally touch the real thing.

The gameplay is quite original. I spent a lot of time on Slay the Spire, which is also a Deckbuilder/Roguelike, but it has a completely difference turn system which is very fresh. Each action has a great impact on the game, and you need to think wisely about if using that card is worth a turn, or not.

Graphics and musics are just perfect. I'm a sucker for this art style.

I see a lot of people posting negative reviews because of balancing problems. I can agree that some mechanics are clearly more powerful than others, but that's also the fun of it, discovering what works or not. I'd like to see corrections and new mechanics added in the future, but for the time being, I think it does the work well enough. My only real critic would be that we have too little control over the contruction of our deck. More ways to banish a card or reroll a treasure would certainly be a nice addition.

It is quite a difficult game, that's for sure. I don't see it as a negative though, quite the opposite. Just take that into consideration if you're not a big fan of struggle. Personally I'm not a good player at all, I'm just a masochist, haha. 'Took me 10 hours to have my first victory, and let just say that a second one might take a lot more time !

I have to echo many of the sentiments of those who have had issues with this game. I want to love Wildfrost, the graphics and presentation are just utterly amazing. The charm that this game imparts is something that keeps drawing me back to play another run, but the immense number of balance issues prevent me from trying this game any further. This is sad given that I absolutely love this genre, and would've loved another game to sink more time into, but in its current form, I cannot recommend it.

Balance issues are as follows:

1. Heroes are generally pretty bad: The heroes that you get to select at the beginning are, more often than not, underwhelming and completely eclipsed by the enemies you'll face, both in terms of health and damage output. This makes the early game significantly more difficult as I found that I was always leaning towards the tougher heroes and neglecting the ones with special abilities, simply to ensure that I had enough output to keep up with the games difficulty ramp.

2. Most companions, charms and treasures are either bad, or just actively make your deck worse: Building a deck around some kind of strategy becomes either rare, or nearly impossible when the choices of companions you're presented with are basically unplayable, or don't meld well with your existing deck. The inability to 'skip' a pick, means you're forced to actively add cards to your deck that make an already bad deck, worse. The charms are all over the place, and the fact that you only get a single charm to pick from when you find them in the dispensers means that quite often you get less out of the route you take then you would otherwise need to keep up. Many of the charms are just straight up bad. I only once in all my runs managed to put some kind of coherent strategy together, and even then it wasn't enough to beat the run.

3. Enemies swarm you: It didn't take long me to realise that this games balance has some serious issues, particularly when waves of enemies keep spawning at a rate far greater than your ability to dispose of them. Given that many enemies can act faster, have more health, and even hit harder than anyone on your team, it makes the swarming even worse. Most of my runs ended because I simply couldn't keep up with the sheer number of enemies that were appearing on the screen. When the mini-boss of each stage appears, if you haven't sufficiently dealt with prior enemies, it can make the game unplayable in terms of difficulty.

I enjoy a challenging game, and don't mind taking the time to learn how to play these better in order to overcome the difficulty, but Wildfrost's balance makes any attempt to trying to do that seemingly pointless. Beating this game seems to come down more to RNG with card choices, and charms then it does with the actual skill of the player. Either you lucked out on an extremely good deck, or your run is just dead.

For the above reasons (and many others that have been mentioned in other reviews), I cannot recommend Wildfrost.

Went into this blind and won my first run. I felt like I got some nice synergies going, but definitely made some mistakes along the way due to not knowing how all the different systems worked. I made a few big blunders during the last fight as well. 

If you are experienced with other roguelike deckbuilders, don't be dissuaded by the negative reviews claiming the game is too difficult.

Dudes with 2 hours in a game expecting to be cruising through everything is laughable.  I personally get excited when a deckbuilder makes me sweat.  I also haven't won a run yet, but I'm excited to get home from work and give it another go.  Maybe the devs should consider adding an easy mode for the whiners?

I love Pinball FX3 and 2 and have played about 530 hours in both games. I didn't like Zen's move to be Epic-inclusive for some time (a year or so), but understand that they had to do it because of financial reasons.

Now that FX is finally available on Steam I was excited and had my wallet ready to buy all tables at launch, something I had done in all those years of FX2 and FX3. But the wait was not worth it.

Table physics are better and more realistic now, not just on real-life machines (Williams tables etc.), but on all of them. As I haven't really played the real machines, the physics of FX3 were ok to me...but I guess, they are better now...so it's a point for Zen.

However, there's not more to like at the moment...

+/good:
1) Physics
2) New tables available

~/average:
You have to buy all tables you own in FX3 again. It's understandable though as nobody works for free.

-/bad:

1) The whole idea to launch FX instead of keeping FX3 and releasing new tables for it

2) UI and menus: I prefer FX3. In the German localization a lot of menus have shortened text that looks odd. Filtering tables and tournaments is tedious and fiddly.

3) Option menu: You cannot even assign buttons freely, but have to use presets. A to shoot, B to change camera like I'm used to from FX3 is not possible.

4) The graphics are a bit better, but at first glance, the remastered FX3 tables just look like there was a cheap filter or effect added. I am used to the old look and graphics...they were good enough.

5) "Modern" full-color DMD: I'm 43 and used to the charm of retro displays. I know some new real-life machines such as The Hobbit have full-color DMDs with actual film footage, but I don't like them either. I prefer the old look.

To sum up, the physics are better than in FX3, you get some new tables, but that's it. I really don't like the decision to develop a whole new engine instead of keeping FX3 and releasing tables for it! Everything was good enough there or even better.

Well i'm not going to bash the pricing cause I know it takes money to acquire more licenses and we can always play fx3 tables if we don't want to re buy.

I honestly thought nothing of it when i saw another metroidvania. they're a dime a dozen these days, and some are downright terrible. this ones quite good. i spent around 3-4 hours in the demo trying to find everything. now i've beaten the game and honestly, it's a bit buggy. because of the physics behind things, and the overall reach of some of the weapons, i unintentionally sequence broke the game several times. I didn't realize it wasn't intentional till it was too late; i still enjoyed myself though. I cant give an honest 100% as intended review because of that though.

Bad things are few: minor (major depending on your progress) bug where anytime i stepped on a spike trap the game would crash. easy enough to avoid, i just had to learn the layout of rooms to do it. dunno why, it never crashed from it originally. if you sequence break, you will end up at bosses you have no business fighting with no ability to avoid their nonsense because you dont have the right tools/abilities.

final score: 9/10. ez win, fun game. thinking of trying it again with one-shot-kill mode enabled but not sure i'm good enough lol.
Such a fun short 3D platformer hope to see more like this from y'all! Great work!

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
    [*][b]Pixel art[/b]: The pixel art, as evident from the screenshots, is gorgeous. There's lots of little details, like the grass being pushed down under your feet as you walk over it, that are easy to overlook but definitely add up to something beautiful.
    [*][b]Grappling, in theory[/b]: The grappling, when it works, is great. Slingshotting yourself over hazards is satisfying.
[/list]

[h1]The Not-As-Good[/h1]
[list]
    [*][b]Grappling, in practice[/b]: There is basically no tutorial section or guidance on how to utilize the grappling system to its greatest potential. Many times during boss fights I would think, [i]how the hell am I supposed to avoid that attack?[/i] because I couldn't find a way to grapple that allowed me to...you know...avoid the attack. This made some fights feel like marathon slogs because of one seemingly impossible-to-dodge attack. (Yes, I'm sure there's been no-hit runs of this game. No, I'm not capable of such a feat.) Many jumping puzzles look possible to do with your current ability set, but are actually meant for later in the game once you have new abilities -- however, no obvious indication is given that you're wasting your time. Many jumps are [i]just[/i] out of reach, and when you don't make them, it creates a moment of "Am I just messing up grappling hook physics, or is this legitimately not possible to do at this point?"
    [*][b]Player guns[/b]: I found that I basically always had to have the trinket that extends the range of my bullets attached because, otherwise, it seemed like I had to basically be kissing the bosses in order to hit them. And when every boss is capable of killing you in 2-3 hits, being so close simply is not a feasible strategy at times unless you've managed to memorize every attack of every phase. With the paltry coinage that enemies dropped, I found myself wanting to avoid fighting enemies because the gunplay is so mediocre at the best of times that I didn't want to risk losing health (or worse, dying and losing a chunk of progress) because I had to be on top of the enemies in order to hit them. I mean, the first gun that the game gives you is basically a rapid-fire charge gun. Why do I have to be four feet away from the target to effectively use it?
    [*][b]Difficulty[/b]: I was prepared for a challenge. I wasn't prepared for an amazingly un-fun challenge. Don't know how to use the grapple effectively because the game didn't teach you the basics? Have fun trying one puzzle jump dozens of times until, somehow, you manage to make it across...only to be faced with [i]another[/i] puzzle jump that requires multiple attempts. And don't you dare die at this point, because death sends you back to your last save and undoes all of your progress -- say goodbye to completed rooms and acquired items, and have fun going to get them again.
    [*][b]Protagonist, or lack thereof[/b]: I read the dialogue. I found bits of lore. And I'm still REALLY confused on who I'm supposed to root for in this game. You'd think the player character, right? Well, no, she blew up a lab full of innocents to kickstart the game, and she thinks a story where everyone in a village drowns for no reason is "humorous." Maybe the characters we fight are the ones to support- ah, no, apparently they kill kids and torture the fae. I played up through three or four major bosses and about a dozen map regions, and I didn't find a single character that I liked and/or wanted to support. EVERYONE seems like a terrible, terrible person.
    [*][b]One grapple per boots-on-the-ground[/b]: Maybe this is fixed by a later ability, but with a grappling hook, doesn't it make sense to want to chain together grapples through difficult areas in order to create a satisfying series of jumps? Locking the grapple ability to once per use until you land on the ground again made every jumping section a case of "How do I get to that patch of ground. Okay, how do I get to THAT patch of ground. Okay, now how about THAT patch of ground." Really feels like a missed opportunity to create some interesting and challenging platforming sections.
    [*][b]Discerning important objects from each other[/b]: Many boss fights were made more difficult for me simply because I couldn't tell what was my bullet, what was an enemy bullet/sword/whatever, what part of the boss (if any) caused contact damage and when, and what was a background element. For instance, with the boss fight with all the swords (for those who played to that part, you know the one), I found that, in phase 2, the swords that locked onto your position were colored like they were in the background right up until they fly directly at you from eight feet away.
    [*][b]Healing, grenades, and One Bar to Charge Them All[/b]: the devs took a page from Hollow Knight's book and tied both your heal and your ranged attack to a chargeable meter. But whereas Hollow Knight made that an obvious and integral part of the game, I found myself chipping away at enemies trying to slowly charge the bar just so I could get another weak heal out of it. I never used the ranged attack other than to open doors that required it because, well, why would I waste my mana on a ranged attack that is VERY easy to miss when I could instead save it for another heal that could potentially save me from having to restart a platforming section or a challenging boss?
[/list]

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
If you're hard up for a "Metroidvania" (I use that term loosely here, since new movement/traversal abilites seem very sparse at least in the early game) and want to try a game with interesting-but-confusing movement mechanics, consider Rusted Moss. If you just want another Metroidvania, grab...literally anything else in the genre, honestly.

EDIT: I just checked, and seriously? Achievements tied to speedrunning with certain completion requirements? Oh, **** off.

Games pretty fun. It's very open after the tutorial boss with lots of places to explore and items to find though some areas are much more difficult to do earlier. I generally haven't liked grapple systems in the games I've played but this one worked for some reason. Combat is pretty eh, it's not really bad but I don't think there is much to write home about. It's mostly trivial with a few exceptions that require a fairly high degree of precision(It's mostly contained to 1 area). A few times they make you do combat in weird scenarios which I like but there are also quite a lot of boring battle rooms where you just fight 3-5 generic enemies in a boring battle arena. Death is fairly punishing though outside of one area save points are pretty abundant. The mediocre combat is made up for by the platforming segments being extremely fun and reward creativity with most of them having multiple ways of going about them depending on your skill with the games physics engine. There is also a ton of speed tech you can learn if you want to go fast. There are few bugs but none of them were very disruptive and it seems like they'll be patched out soon.

Took me about 17 hours to 100% but others may spend much longer. Pick it up if you like very open metroidvanias with lots of fun movement tech.

Overall I had a good time. There are things that truly impress me and sometimes I'm reminded this still being an indie game. If you compare this to other (one man) indie games, then it surpasses many. You're at the wrong place if you're expecting triple A production values. I also like this being 3D and the genre chosen. We don't see enough of those on the indie side. This is a good first game that stands on its own. But you can also see there is room for improvement that should be easy to accomplish. I have the feeling the next game is going to be better. It was worth supporting and I'm looking forward to whatever comes next.

So, I don't know if there are different endings or anything like that, but I have at least completed the "Feed" options on all 3 levels with Renfield, so I think I have some ability to say certain things. 

Game is awesome. The pixelated style is a common choice for these roguelite games, but the combination of the music, the animations, and the sometimes goofy moments makes me wonder what the movie will be like. Which...is probably what the developers want, but I have to say, they do it well. So whatever gripes I may have being advertised to by a videogame are all unimportant since it worked >:)

Some visual/gameplay issues I noticed. Hitboxes are not very defined. I can sometimes get right into an enemy's face without getting hit, and the others it feels like I got suckerpunched from nowhere. And that is just the melee enemies. The enemy bullets are hard to keep track of. I had a buddy watch me from the side and with all the shimmying about I was doing to hit the enemies, I neglected the bullets that were apparently obvious. Now, that might be my ADHD at play, but I was definitely getting better about avoiding most of the onslaught of projectiles. Another issue is the controls. Not having a cursor from your mouse made things a little wonky in the menu screen. At first, the game crashed on exit, but it seems that was fixed pretty quickly. Also, don't expect to win...for some time. Or maybe I am just bad at the game (:

Ideas for the future? I am not going to tell the developers how to play the game, but some things I had questions on are how hard it is to understand anything. For example, the Victims you are to save or kill...I think an achievement is related to this option, but I can't determine how to go about it. I both saved and killed the Cheerleader in the first level with Renfield, but there was no obvious difference in result, save for time remaining upon reaching the boss room and the amount of money that was rewarded. Is money going to be more important in a future update? Also, the shop was a little surprising. It took me a bit to realize there were other tabs lol. Also also, the coffin was something I wasn't sure what it did until I realized I had to buy it multiple times. I had thought its effect was an upgrade I got in a run.

All-in-all, the game is hectic, visually stimulating, probably a good game to watch for streamers, and if this is just the beginning, then I am looking forward to what the developers bring in the future.

I will keep playing just to see if beating the levels in both Feed and Save options for both playable characters will do something. Then I will play to see if there are good synergies.

This game has really surprised me. I didn't expect to love it as much as I do, but there is so much creativity and passion that was put into the design of this retro FPS. The art style is so unique, and every level is different, with so many varied environments that have tons of artistry put into them. Gameplay is pretty straightforward - plays a lot like a combination of Doom, Quake and Serious Sam - however, there are a few creative weapons that make the gunplay stand out from other modern throwback shooters. illWill is fantastic, and I hope that it gets the attention that it deserves, because the developer has clearly put a lot of love and effort into this project.

Notable innovations to the card-battler genre from an artistic and mechanical standpoint. Board positioning is essential, as is paying attention to the minute details of enemy effects and attack patterns.

This game is extremely punishing, and for me that is very motivating to keep playing. This is not a game where you can afford to zone out, and it holds tension even in the early battles of each run.

However, there are some changes that would probably make the game more fun. I think a system of re-rolling hero selections would be nice, because it's not fun to feel the need to play a hero that is almost identical to one you played in your previous run. There's some needlessly difficult interactions such as Monch insta-killing your avatar. It made me laugh, but it's really not necessary to have as many small "gotchas" like this to keep the game challenging.

I'm also not sure that forcing card selection from chests is necessary. Similar games such as Slay the Spire let the player opt to take nothing at all, which is often preferable than making an off-synergy pick. The large hand-size and bell re-draw system does already mitigate the drawbacks of having a dud in your deck, but I think the game is challenging enough that it could support players running leaner, meaner strategies earlier.

Or, as much as I like the injury mechanic, maybe just remove it or make it reduce the creature's stats incrementally rather than by half? 

Who knows without play-testing, but I'd consider some graceful ways to slightly re-balance.

Been waiting for these collections for a long time now. So glad they finally got around to making them. Mega Man Battle Network may not have been my intro into Mega Man, that being Mega Man 8, but it's what definitely solidified my love for the Mega Man franchise as a whole.

Pros:
- Amazing music.
- Lovable cast of characters, both friends and foes alike.
- Beautiful locations, both in Lan's world and in Mega Man's.
- Fun gimmicks per each entry, such as Cross Fusion, Double Soul, etc.
- Amazing pixel art.
- An overall very exciting and enjoyable adventure.

Cons:
- Random battle shenanigans being a wee bit too frequent for my taste. (At least for MMBN1. Been a long time since I've played these games, so I don't quite remember if the rest are as... Saturated with random battles as MMBN1 is.)

Will update review accordingly.

Battle Network 1: very much shows it was the first in the series. Random battles are frequent, and its the only one of the 6 that requires you to use escape chips to run, so you have to waste folder spots to have the chance to run from a battle. 
That gripe aside, its a fun game, and the sequels fix a lot of past issues.

Battle Network 2: adds so much more compared to BN1. More areas to explore Battle system tweaked for the better, and the story is pretty good.

Battle Network 3:
This is in my opinion the best BN game. Battle system has been expanded upon greatly, it introduces the customization system to make your play style your own. (a few complaints where you have to use certain upgrades for specific parts in the story) Speaking of, the story is my favorite of the 3. And the post game has so much do do. This was unfortunately the game they decided to split the game in 2 which makes you have to trade to get all of the chips. 

Overall I am happy this series finally has a modern way to play, and I hope we can see more MegaMan titles in the future.

Max Mode Buster essentially lets you skip the constant random encounters that can make the games tedious.

My only gripe is that MegaMan's voice is off in the game selection menu. I wonder if the voice actor only did a single take for most of his lines. Maybe some tuning with an "electronic" filter (to mimic the PET audio output from the show) could have helped.

Things I Like: 
+ DooM Eternal combat in Clustertruck. Like if Doom Guy was in Mad Max: Fury Road
+ When you grapple somebody, your dude has a chance of yelling 'GET OVER HERE!' 
+ Gets to the action fast and only lets up when you die. 
+ Only a couple loading screens. Some levels fade into one another. 
+ Talking about levels, it deviates from the regular 'convoy' theme at times and gives you trains, planes, exploding barrel trucks and even the sandworm from Dune. No, I'm not kidding. There is a giant sand worm. 
+ The grapple hook is free to use with any weapon. Nothing beats grappling to a group of enemies, letting the minigun rip and tear them apart! 
+ The fast paced, metal soundtrack. 
+ The enemies are styled like punk / post apocalyptic goons. 
+ The easily affordable price. 
+ One of the achievements for falling off the train is called 'Follow The Damn Train, CJ!'
+ Sometimes the enemies kill themselves by jumping and missing a moving truck, which is very kind of them. And funny. 

Things I Don't Like: 
- The pixel style of graphics: The indie shooter's unimpressive go-to for art style. Dusk. Nightmare Reaper. Cultic. Ultrakill. Gloomwood. And now MeatGrinder. It's just my preference. I don't like it and I grew up playing Star Wars Dark Forces 1+2! Although, this one is actual 3D all the way through. 
- Within 28 minutes I had a lot of repeated voice lines from the protagonist. I even turned down the frequency in which he speaks, but it didn't stop him from saying 'I LOVE THIS SONG' every time the music changes. 

Overall, an absolutely killer title for the price. 
And I totally recommend listening to the Mad Max Fury Road chase music if you get bored of the metal.

While the game is short, I highly recommend it! This is one of the very few games where combat is not the main focus. So it may seem easy but it is a nice relaxing game! The puzzles weren't too complex, nor were they over used. For such a small team the game looks wonderful as well!

This game is so good lucking, great sounding, and very fun to play.  Innovative and challenging.  Highly recommend for hardcore deckbuilder roguelite players.

This is definitely one of my favorite roguelike deckbuilders, up there with Slay the Spire and Across the Obelisk. The art and music are fantastic and the game is fun. There several different factions, each with multiple playstyles to ensure each run feels different. It's a difficult game. It definitely encourages you to think out every move. It punishes your for mistakes but it doesn't feel unfair. The runs are also short enough that losing doesn't feel terrible. My only outstanding question at this point is how replayable the game is once you beat the boss.

At the time of writing this the game is getting review bombed and I'm not sure why. It definitely doesn't deserve it. People are saying it's too hard and unbalanced. Yes the game is difficult, but to me it feels about the same level of difficulty as Slay the Spire. I've done about 20ish runs or so at this point and made it to the final boss twice. I died there once due to bad luck and once due to my own misplays. I would also disagree that the game is unbalanced. Each playstyle (thorns, poison, frost, etc.) can be super powerful if built into, but they all have their counters. The game will try to find a weakspot in your deck, but you can learn from that and exploit the enemies weaknesses too. 

All in all, it's an awesome game that deserves more love.

the difficulty of enemies and platforming can be quite intense depending on what order you do/find things in, but it's amazing so far. reminds me a lot of momodora, which is a great thing.

A fantastic game! It's way more meaty than I thought it would've been. Almost four hours in and it feels like I've only just scratched the surface. Navigating the world with the grappling hook feels extremely intuitive and the gunplay is tight. Movement overall feels very good, which I'd imagine is important for a game that highlights the unique way of traversing levels, and platforming -- while difficult -- feels fair because even if you mess up a jump, you respawn on the last stable ground you landed up which is very convenient when later areas have difficult platforming sections. 

Also Fern is cute. I want to pull her ponytail.

This game is great. It's a Survivors-like with a heavy focus on upgrades and build tweaks, and it blends together perfectly. Minus the English translation.

At first I was a bit confused by the rough translation, but now that I understand the upgrade system I adore this game. If you like upgrading and tweaking builds to trigger different moves and effects you will have a great time with this Survivors-like.

I like Wildlands - it's a visually appealing deckbuilder that feels polished and very reminiscent of games like Slay the Spire / Monster Train, but it's much easier to pick this up and play it for a short period of time and move on - it feels like the game gets to the meat of what makes these games interesting very quickly.

That said, I'm a big deckbuilder fan and have spent hundreds of hours playing these kinds of games, and it took me ten hours before I won a run, and I feel like rng has a big part in whether you get the necessary tools to win or not.  It also doesn't feel as if there's as much content in this game (e.g. # of cards, # of tribes, no co-op) in comparison with the others.

I wouldn't use this game as an introduction to deckbuilders - if you like Monster Train you'll probably like this game, but I wouldn't buy this as a gift for a kid or a casual.

Fun game, has some turns that make you think, fantastic presentation. Love the diversity of cards and buffs, makes for a lot of variety between runs. Feels very much like a rogue-like. Looking forward to finishing the unlocks and seeing what the full library ends up playing like.

Highly recommend to anyone who is a fan of Frogwares' Holmes games. It is similar to Chapter One but with a few improvements. Improved deduction screen (takes some getting used to though) and no combat in this iteration. Maps/locales are more varied but there are less side quests/side stories to enjoy. The game is definitely shorter than the previous game but is not lacking in quality. Considering the challenges they faced developing it I would say they did an admirable job.

Recommend buying at full price if a big fan or on sale if not but you still enjoy detective/investigation games.

My first review ever, but I feel compelled to leave one because I cannot understand all the negative reviews on this game. I love it. The look, sound, and feel are all perfect. It puts a new, highly addictive spin on the deckbuilder genre. It is hard and needs balance, but even in its current state, it’s flat out a blast to play and we’ll worth $20. Most importantly, it plays flawlessly on Steam Deck with controller support, which is a rarity for deckbuikders.

The game is fun and engaging if you're a fan of planning ahead and strategizing. While there are many actions happening in every turn, all enemy actions are telegraphed multiple turns ahead and once you understand the order in which they are executed, you can plan accordingly.  All those negative reviews criticising the balancing aspect are imo by players who do not enjoy this planning and don't do it thoroughly enough as it is easy to overlook something (which may even get you killed). In 4 hours I played 4 runs, won 2 of them, and died once to the final boss and once midway through. Balancing seems fine. Or maybe I am just lucky :P

If I were to criticise something its that the different abilities / status effects are not explained ideally so some interactions are initially uncleaer. This fixes itself with some more experience though.

Very entertaining card game that manages to stand out from the roguelike card game horde with good artstyle and a unique battling system that reminds you of duelyst. Deep enough for replayability, however the main flaw right now is GLARING balancing issues, (Heroes are nowhere near to average in power level, same with followers, impossible to build around, card pool has no rerolls). However, these are fixable problems, and easily fixable at that. The core of the game is solid and charming, so expect this one to stay. Solid 7/10 as of no0.

Even 20 years later I still have a soft spot for anything that reminds me of the original Unreal, I remember before I had my own computer I would play it with friends in the game cafes back when multiplayer games were just getting popular, they only had 5 games installed, Starcraft, Half-life, Quake, Diablo2, and Unreal. It's a shame they are no longer on Steam, granted I think the genre has been going downhill after UT2004, they tried but it could capture the magic -  that awesome music, simple gameplay, and just satisfying carnage. This game attempts to capture the spirit and the soul of those games, but it also adds a twist to it which I did not enjoy. 

Everything outside of the core gameplay is a bit lacking, the only thing this game does really well is just the feel for the weapons and the character movement (except the bots, they are kinda junky). The current story mode only has about 70 minutes of content, so you really not getting a lot for the price. Now, you can play against bots in the custom games, but the AI pathing is very bad, pretty much making it pointless, especially in the domination and the "capture the flag" mode. Also, I feel like the maps need to be bigger, the bots respawn almost right on top of me, and there is never a window where I can actually benefit from killing them, it's easier to just ignore them, maybe there needs to be a respawn delay.

Interestingly, this game is not what you might think, I don't want to say much more than that to avoid spoilers, but it's not in a classic format where you progress in the arena, although I kinda wish it was, something like UT2004 would be more appropriate here, I would prefer a team management game. There are some gimmicks in the narrative that don't work, every time I am trying to enjoy the gameplay it has to interrupt me in order to do some narrative gimmicks. If I compare it directly to Unreal Gold, there is only 1 big stage in this game, and even that is only 10-15 minutes,  the tension that I felt running away from Unreal predators is just not there. 

I am seeing a lot of praise for the narrative here, but outside of some funny cheese from 90s there is really not a lot to say, it's very cliche at this point to have any kind of mind games. If anything, I think the Unreal story part was told through a good level design and navigation, and I find that many stages in this game didn't get the same treatment. 

[h1]Pros: [/h1]

(+) With the exception of the AI, I think the character movement and the weapons feel good. I find the game plays a bit too fast compared to  UT so tracking with guns can be a bit unpredictable if you play on high difficulty, but if we can just make the hardest AI less teleporty, I think it would be fine.

(+) The game seems to use the same or at least similar sound effects, for the most part, the actual atmosphere is very nostalgic. I mean the music is not as good, but I mean, how many games have better music than UT, not many. I appreciate a little bit of 90s action voice lines.

(+) I do like the visuals, but I think the dev is missing the point with some of the levels, it depends on the location, I think there is a lot of room for improvement, you could even rely more on platforming to create challenges since you can move so much in this game, don't be afraid to create more verticality for the player to jump around.

[h1] Feedback: [/h1]

[u] Enemies & Level Design [/u] - one very big problem with this game is that many enemies are not actually fun to kill. Like, you have these guns that have nice impact feel to them, but some of the story parts have these stupid projectiles that you can't see or some random birds. I have not seen any decent enemies that are not bots until one of the last stages. Honestly, you should completely remove all of that poorly color-coded junk, all enemies should be chunky and fun to kill, try to combine Unreal with Doom for the story parts.

The arena stages are too small specifically for the team modes. Also, you want to put the respawns a bit further back so the bots don't come back instantly when you kill them.

You need to make longer levels with more optional navigation, the only stage in this game that kinda matches what I expected from this game is the one with the robot boss. It often feels like you are running through an empty level with nothing to do. Also on a side note, try to avoid overusing any dark corners like the stage with the acid, even if the texture is not great it will always look better than just dark wall.

[u] AI [/u] - the pathing on the AI is very bad, and yet if you play on the hardest difficulty it's very hard to track them with a gun, the movement in this game feels maybe 30% faster than UT so it's almost like they are teleporting around (assuming they don't get stuck like they often do).

[u] Narrative [/u] - if that is what you want to do it's fine, my problem is that it feels like the game takes the control away from me all the time. Like, let me play for 30 minutes, then inject some narrative you know, if you play mind games every 5 minutes it's not going to feel like an Unreal game, you still need some immersion with the level exploration, and that means stop interrupting the gameplay.

[b] Overall Thoughts on EA 4/14/23: [/b]

I think the game gets the atmosphere and the gameplay right for the most part, but when you look into the details, like the magic of Unreal level design, it needs a lot of work. The story is a bit too much in your face, you want it to feel more natural, don't force mind games on player, more game, fewer interruptions. Probably not worth what the dev is asking for it, I expected more than 70 minutes, or at least an arena mode that is fun to play (the AI sucks). 

Unreal has some sentimental value for me so... I figure many people would find this a bit underwhelming, but it has a few nice things going for it.

It's a beautiful early access release that doesn't feel like early access.  UI is polished, the art style is unique and beautiful.  It tells a story and makes you feel like you're role playing in a fairy tale right from the first load screen!  Fabledom is a crowning achievement in the genre of chill, peaceful colony builders that diverges from the usual formula of Crisis Management, Traffic Management, Strategic Warfare and Complex Supply Chains to deliver something wholesomely unique that has not been done before.  It feels like a more aesthetically pleasing spiritual sibling to Foundation, while being different enough to have an identity all its own - and it has romance and flying pigs!  What more could you ask for?  Highly recommended!

this is my first game review but i wanted to make one for this game as i really hope it gets some love and i want to share how much i enjoyed this game and hope its a sign of more Tron games to come 

I'm a big fan of the Tron IP and it's such a shame that so little is done with it in terms of games. So when i heard they were making a VN detective game i was so excited as its a part of the universe we don't see much if at all and i think this really delivers that experience 

Set in a separate area from the movies lets this stand on its own, even though we got a short time with these characters we still learn alot about this world and how it has and is still evolving and changing, the talk of past wars, enemies and friends, new factions and ideologies. I want to talk more and spend more time here.

The game is short and i can see people getting annoyed with the puzzle gameplay but i found it a nice change of pace.

Overall a great time and i hope there is more to come

Dye The Bunny takes the seemingly innocent and cheerful Easter tradition of egg hunting and plunges it into the depths of horror, creating a thrilling gaming experience that will make you think twice about following a rabbit down a hole.

As little Ellie embarks on her Easter egg hunt adventure, the game masterfully blends whimsy and terror, immersing players in a dark and twisted world beneath the surface. The graphics and sound design evoke a haunting atmosphere, with eerie music and unsettling visuals that keep you on the edge of your seat.

Dye The Bunny's narrative is both chilling and captivating, making it difficult to look away even when you're on the verge of screaming. The game's developers have taken a creative risk by combining the innocence of childhood with the darkness of horror, and the result is a unique experience that will leave a lasting impression on players.

Overall, Dye The Bunny is a must-play for horror enthusiasts and those seeking a fresh twist on a classic holiday celebration. Its chilling atmosphere, engaging gameplay, and memorable storyline make it an Easter horror game that you won't soon forget. But be warned - you may never see the Easter Bunny in the same way again.

I feel mixed about this game, but right now the user reviews sit at 60% and I don't really think it deserves that.

I kinda forced my way through the game Slay The Spire, but I got all the achievements so I like to think I'm good at these kind of games.

People say this game is badly balanced but I don't agree with that.  The runs are just short so every fight needs to feel lethal.  That being said I do think this game FEELS random.  There is just so much going on in the game that it's super difficult to keep up with and I found myself not understanding how I lost. This game has a lot going for it, and a lot that could be improved. Wildfrost nails the art, mechanics, acension system, UX and  ease of understanding. Everything follows a consistent logic which although it can take many tries to learn the specifics it has never left me feeling like they made a mistake. 

I would say that the game falls flat when it comes to consistency between runs. RNG is expected for the roguelike genre but in this case it affects every aspect of the game including the most important of your 2 starting units, the leader, which has to remain on the board the entire fight and if it dies its game over. All fights come as one of 2 versions, with a different set of enemies for each. The issue with this is that they can be WILDLY different in how tough they are. The events between fights are also mostly random - this is alright as the events are balanced enough and the shop events even things out because it's never required to buy a card at a shop, and the coins can be saved up at bad shops until you find one with the items you want.

By far the most aggravating RNG comes at the very beginning of the run with the choice of 1 of 3 randomly generated heroes. Some of the heroes are leagues stronger than others. It makes a huge difference in getting a run off the ground. Unfortunately, resetting after having a bad hero selection counts as a loss so if you care about winstreaks or win rates this adds frustration. I prefer not to start scum but winning feels way more achievable when I start with a good hero. 
This actually gets WORSE with the ascension perks as you only have one hero available from each faction. The starting faction is the most powerful, the 2nd one is good, and the 3rd faction is the worst. So although I will prefer using one of the factions I do not have much of a choice when the one hero from it sucks. Factions determine your starting deck and a large amount of the available cards during the run, which makes this very important.

The biggest RNG in fights occurs at the first boss fight. It spawns with either the King Moko or the 2 tall Mecha boss. King moko is essentiatlly a 7-turn death timer, in which you have to kill the boss before he attacks or else he wipes out your entire board. On top of that he has 60 health which is very high at that point in the game, so the only way to beat him is through having units attack him enough times that the attack bonus he gives builds up and is enough to chew through his health. The mecha boss on the other hand only had 18 health in the first phase, and 15 health in the second phase, and does 2 damage. The attack is super easy to tank in the second phase and 18 health is only twice as much as the regular enemies. I don't mind the fight being difficult, but the variation in balancing is laughable.

Now for the reasons why I like the game. I'll start with listing specific mechanics outside of the basics you're taught in the tutorial and through text:

combat order goes top down, from the inside of the board outward starting on the enemies side and then letting the players side go through actions. All effects tick after attacks have happened.

Noomlings make cards completely free to play, as such if you have multiple cards with noomlings in your hand you can play all of them without using your turn

Companions can be put into reserve (you still have them but they're not in your deck for battle) at any time, with a limit of 3 companions going into battle

All effects are useful on every unit type, including bosses. This is handy because it means effect synergies can't get hard countered, and remain viable in each fight. The only exception is that some boss and non-boss units have snow resist, which means that they can only have 1 snow stacked at one time. Snow is an effect which delays that units attack timer by the amount of snow, this stops the player from being able to prevent a bosses attack entirely. This is different to slay the spire, which has units which are immune to different types of effects. 

Mechanics like 'sacrificing' where friendly cards have to be killed to gain a bonus are not treated any differently from any other way of a card dying - in one instance I had a card which applies 4 overburn get sacrificed by another unit, and it ended up applying the overburn to my own unit, killing it. Heroes are also treated like any companions by other cards because my own hero got killed when another card triggered its sacrifice on the row it was in.

Why do I like the game, even with those issues I've described? I still find a lot of fun in the strategy that comes with every decision made - whether to go with what's best in the next fight, or try to find a broken synergy 2 fights from now. To build a good deck it's always a good idea to have more than one strong unit and synergy because many of the fights test decks in specific areas. There is one fight where the enemies all have a lot of block shielding which blocks individual instances of damage. If you used a strong single damage dealer to get through previous fights it adds a lot of challenge because the attacks of that damage dealer will only remove one block, the same as if it did 1. To defeat the enemies you need either a strong defensive setup which lets you chip away at the opponent's blocks or many fast attacking units to destroy their threatening units quickly.

The most fun I've had with this game was naming my cards and messing around with OP charm combos, when I beat the game with my leader called 'YOUR MOTHER'. Now she resides at the final boss fight every time, with all of the broken combos which I created with those units alongside her. Every time I've gotten back to that point since I have lost to YOUR MOTHER I'm determined to build a more OP deck so I can see what happens when I beat the fight for a second time.
The perfect game for masochists like me.

This game is awesome! Sadly, it's being review-bombed at the moment by followers of a popular Chinese streamer, which is really a shame (and something I hope doesn't negatively impact the devs)... 

But the game is super fun, and feels pleasantly-challenging in it's current state. I can see the devs making some balance tweaks over the coming days/weeks, but it's super fun and enjoyable - as long as you aren't expecting to win every single run without thinking! :)

The game is fun and beneath the balancing issues is a interesting deck builder. But I have to agree with most negative reviews here. I LOVED the demo but what I think this game desperately need is a more divers path of enemies. For the most part you can make some pretty busted builds as usual for a rogue-like, but enemy encounters can just outright counter your deck strategy very usually since the game does not offer much diversity with deck creativity. If you could at least have two options in the path as to what enemy you are to face, I could enjoy myself without the frustration of praying as to WHO I will face. 
So prepare to be leaning HARD into the RNG luck of not ONLY what you get but what enemies you will face. You either synergize or die.

[h1]Experienced on the Meta Quest 2[/h1]

You can view my initial impressions review & gameplay here: https://youtu.be/BcbFdvH3lx8

If you enjoyed playing Kill It With Fire (Non-VR) then you're going to enjoy this VR port. It is a bit on the janky side though. However, it's just fun to be an agent of chaos in VR.

You get to kill Spiders in a plethora of manners. You have silencers, shotguns, revolvers, flamethrowers, molotovs, explosives, bazookas, a frying pan, etc. You can set the whole world on fire with your single-minded quest to kill any possible spider that may be out there.

If you enjoy explosives, this game is for you. If you're an aspiring arsonist, this game for you. If you just hate spiders, this game is for you. You can follow the objectives for each map or just do your own thing. The only thing that matters in the end is to kill all the spiders by any means necessary.

Game is running on the Unreal Engine. On my RTX 3080, on high graphical settings, I did experience some severe frame rate drops / stutters ... usually when lots of stuff exploded. I should have probably lowered the graphics to medium though. You have full locomotion or teleportation available, along with smooth or snap turning. You can play comfortable seated, as there is a button crouch, height adjustment, along with magnet hands. There is some jank though grabbing items or using your inventory, etc. 

[b]Rate 7/10.[/b]

It is a lot like battle brothers and incredibly charming, I love a lot about this.
Why do I not recommend it? Because difficulty is done poorly in my opinion.
What do I mean? Well, let me explain.
Generally, challenge is a curve, while your strength goes steadily up, most games start out very hard, you become stronger and the curve swings down, you have reached a point where your new skills let you feel powerful. Then slowly the curve swings back up and new opponents and challenges approach, which allow you to truly be put to the test with the things you learned. Then you slowly gain new skills again and it becomes easier, so you feel rewarded about your progression.
This loop is how most games work.

Now, wartales instead is... two straight lines overlapping. You level up? All enemies instantly level up. You gain a new member? All enemy parties are suddenly bigger.
This is both immersion breaking and makes combat a bit of a slog. Battle brothers did this too, but to a far, far less noticable degree, where enemies felt like they slowly ramped up and when you got stronger there were still plenty of weak and fragile bandits.
Here suddenly even the refugees are 12 man parties swarming you like they think they're zerg, when they started out as 3 man. This means every combat is the same level of challenge, you never feel rewarded for getting stronger, because you know combat is just getting harder instead, so instead of saying "yay I got a new great member!" you think "god damn it, now I'll have to fight 12 enemies every fight... I hope they don't all get the buff that makes them do 5% hp every attack".

There is no reward for stronger, because enemies are always scaled up to your level, in fact it would almost seem that the more I advance, the weaker I get, as enemies scale even harder. It's... not very fun and it turns combat into a slog.
Battle brother does it very well, where enemies don't really get stronger, but gradually stronger parties with new enemies show up.
They don't do that here, it's just level 5 refugees with torches burning you down, and super elite bandits.
It's still the same bandits as in the early game, but now they're super boosted and there's 20 of them.

I want to recommend this game, but they just need to rework the way they do enemy scaling. Because like this? Well, the only result is always gonna be an immersion breaking slog of combat.
Improving your mercenary group should let you have some moments of victory.

Because when every battle is the same difficulty, and you never feel like you are growing stronger, and you're always fighting the same enemies scaled exactly to be as strong as you, every battle is completely forgetable and you stop caring about progressing.

You have some amazing systems, in my opinion the way battle actually plays out is very good, but the scaling is too much. When it comes to enemies and scaling, learning from battle brothers might be a godsent.
But I somewhat doubt they will.

My immediate response to the ending was "NO! [i]NO![/i] THAT CAN'T BE IT! [i][b]THERE MUST BE MORE![/b][/i]"

So yes, I liked the game so much that my biggest issue is how short it is. Unlike [u]Portal[/u], [u]MEATGRINDER[/u] doesn't really have the writing or story—nay, not even the pretence for a thrilling climax. Thrilling set pieces, most certainly, each one better than the last, but the game doesn't so much reach a satisfying finish as it does just end. There are a couple of cool bosses in the game but we don't get one very last boss to wrap things up, like a giant robot spider using tanks as skates.

But those set pieces really are good, I must say. From the very second level, jumping between trucks and flinging away bandits running and jumping at you never stops being fun, and then they just keep introducing new elements in each level to make it so much more fun and exciting! Having said that, while the final two levels are visually striking and dynamic, enemy placement is repeated and the gameplay loop doesn't flow as well so shooting enemies isn't particularly fun in them. However, as the levels are pretty damn short and it IS an amazing visual spectacle, it's not a problem at all as you'll only go through them once anyway.

I have a few more issues:
[list]
    [*]Not all weapons are created equally. The minigun feels and sounds rather underpowered compared to everything else and it heats up way too quickly. Also, there's really no reason to use the pistols once you've gotten the second weapon.
    [*]Hard Mode is, ironically, too hard. I think it's fine to punish the player more for falling on the road but a one-hit kill is far too unforgiving when the game is so chaotic that what you're standing on can just leave you far too suddenly and get you killed, or car placements are too far spread out that it's impossible to advance. 
    [*]The game is... visually weird? When enemies are close to me, it's hard to register a lot. I kick at them but there's little in the way of visceral feedback that tells me I've actually done it apart from the enemy suddenly not being in front of me anymore. Same goes for when I'm shooting them with the pistols. I guess this combines with the minigun issue of weapons lacking solid feedback, which could be remedied by sound effects.
    [*]I get you're inspired by [u]ULTRAKILL[/u], what with the graphics and that whole three-line intro bit at the start, but those things are just cheesy. Those things aren't what make [u]ULTRAKILL[/u] great and having those elements don't make you [u]ULTRAKILL[/u]. This game sets itself apart in so many wonderful ways while being alike in so many wonderful ways so those things just baffle me, really.
[/list]
Overall, though, I loved [u]MEATGRINDER[/u]. The sheer creativity and thrill behind every moment of the game makes me very excited for what Vampire Squid do next. I WILL say that, while I can appreciate a game focusing on gameplay over story, there's no reason why they can't intersect and work off each other. All games are enriched with context and boomer shooters are no different; [u]Metal: Hellsinger[/u]'s one example of this and even [u]DOOM[/u] 2016 uses the themes of the original [u]Doom[/u]'s tropes as good storytelling devices, from the Doom Slayer's violent reactions to everything and his lack of speaking. 

I'm not going to ask for long cutscenes and exposition. This game is, after all, about flow, and cutscenes like that would be just as flowbreaking as Hard Mode with all the deaths on the road. But surely the gameplay itself could tell the story; voice lines from your avatar that aren't pop culture references, enemy designs and voice lines, and even the set pieces themselves could result from decisions made by everyone involved in this crazy imminent pile-up. All the same, this was really cool.

Even though the point is obviously to survive the 20 waves, it still feels more of a pointless endeavor than other games within this genre. It may be because the enemies are all autopathing looking like they are in a MOBA going to a tower, but they are just doing large loops around the map I think, with no destination. 

There are good bits that, if changed quite a bit, may be fun in the future. But I think the majority of positive reviews currently posted are probably less than genuine. I would have returned it even for the $3, but I took my dog out for a walk and didn't see I left it on for 2.5 hours.

I had high hopes for Sidestep Legends and I really wanted to like it because the concept is neat, but I feel like I keep going back to it and it just doesn't quite click for me. The player is offered a traditional bullet heaven control scheme, with WASD or gamepad stick usage and fixed camera, or one closer to MOBAs with the mouse doing all the heavy lifting. It's all about sidesteps, avoiding enemy attacks, traps and more, with a handful of enemy types roaming on predetermined paths as the mobs in a MOBA unless the player bothers them. Unlike the waves of Vampire Survivors clones, Sidestep Legends barely features any attack that can be used to damage opponents while moving, so players will be required to keep switching between moving and standing still, to dodge and to attack respectively. This is a fun take on the genre for sure, as it adds an extra layer of strategy and decision-making, on top of a higher skill ceiling.

The issue is that it doesn't really feel too rewarding. The enemies are not very varied, and they pose a challenge pretty much only because the player has to stop to fight them, with an initial attack range pre-upgrades that is quite laughable. The base attacks and speeds are also superlow, though upgrades make them a lot more satisfying eventually. The map has XP gems and coins spawn all across, with even treasure chests and challenges filling in the blanks, but often these happen far away from enemies who, remember, follow predetermined paths. The game actively pushes you away from the action a lot of the time, with traps like gas waves, fire areas and hooks pulling the player back for extra challenge. This is the game's incentive to have the player moving... but again, you are supposed to stop to attack, which means that most of the time you will not be attacking, as it doesn't take long before you are looking at a couple dozen enemies and traps are spawning everywhere. 

Couple all this with fairly unimpressive 3D visuals and a skill tree that's packed with tons of expensive yet minor upgrades, and I just can't say that I truly enjoy or want to recommend this game yet. Even when the upgrades become more satisfying, some higher level skills and characters are unlocked and you're battling against a giant boss, at its core Sidestep Legends feels like you're fighting against the game's design trying to slow your every move and attack more so than the hundreds of identical minions you encounter in a run. A good bullet heaven and a good MOBA both make you feel swift and powerful, and unfortunately that feeling is too rare here for me to recommend the game as of now. I plan to revisit it in the future because it's still in Early Access and I believe the concept can achieve a lot more with some balancing and design tweaks.

One of the things I enjoyed most about Plantera 2 is the variety of plants and animals available in the game. There's a wide range of different species that can be grown, from fruit trees to flowers and vegetables. There's also a great variety of animals that can be raised, such as chickens, cows, and sheep. Additionally, there's a large number of items to unlock, such as gardening equipment and farm decorations.

The gameplay in Plantera 2 is very fun and addictive. The game starts with a small and simple farm, but as the player earns more money, they can expand the farm and purchase new plants and animals. There's also the possibility of hiring workers to help care for the animals and plants. However, as the farm grows, it also becomes more difficult to manage, making the game challenging.

The graphics in Plantera 2 are excellent, with a lot of attention to detail. The characters and animals are well-designed and the colors are bright and cheerful. The soundtrack is relaxing and helps create a peaceful and pleasant atmosphere.

Although I enjoyed Plantera 2 very much, there are some weaknesses in the game. The lack of a plot or story can make the game a bit monotonous and without a clear goal. Additionally, the gameplay can become repetitive after a while, especially if the player has already unlocked most of the plants and animals.

Overall, Plantera 2 is a fun and engaging game with many plants, animals, and items to unlock. While the lack of a plot may be somewhat disappointing for some players, the gameplay itself is very satisfying and addictive. If you enjoy simulation and farm management games, I recommend giving Plantera 2 a try.
