I was really enthusiastic to see the gameplay previews of Boundary, and now that it's here, I am hoping this game succeeds. Where a lot of other FPS titles on Steam have brought unique concepts to the table and stumbled in a few key areas (content delivery being a huge issue), I hope Boundary's dev team learns and is able to create a living game that improves over time. So far, I am pleased to see the developers responding to English-language feedback and I hope that continues further into the game's development cycle. 

Since Boundary is releasing in Early Access and I'm writing this review on Day 1, I am hoping to write down a few thoughts to inform prospective players. Following are some plusses and minuses that I've experienced in the game as-is:

PROS:
-Delivers fantastically well on the premise. The sound quality is impeccable as well as the visual fidelity, and Boundary is very immersive as a result. You can see tracers and the Sun reflected off your helmet. Your character breathes heavily and you can hear the oxygen rushing out of your suit. Sound doesn't travel in space, and the game is starkly quiet as a result (but still full of rich sound design) I have spent the last hour in game goggling at my surroundings with my headphones at full volume to appreciate what this game has going on. It's really well done in all aspects, including in the menus.
-The game's visual design is great- the UI/HUD elements and ingame assets fit really well with the theme and everything goes together nicely. It remains to be seen where cosmetics will be taken (and I really hope against all odds they stick to the theme of high-tech space). 
-The gunplay is extremely satisfying when it's flowing well- when everything clicks it feels really well done. AAA quality for sure.
-The movement is mostly well considered and feels very fluid despite your character being in a clunky spacesuit. The grapple and boost mechanic are great for getting around.
-I appreciate the small aesthetic flairs- the weapon animations are nearly fantastic throughout (with a few small janks here and there), and I am a big fan of the character flairs given to each class. 
-Stability is great so far. Have not experienced any frame drops, lags, stutters, or crashes (thank UE4)

CONS:
-The translation quality to English is very poor at this time. A few things remain in Chinese, and the menu elements are pretty poorly translated throughout. The entire game needs a thorough pass by a trained localization team. 
-The HUD (ESPECIALLY the customization menu) has some information but is lacking many critical details. I saw a community guide up earlier that EXPLAINED each side pod's function, which is notably lacking from the game itself. Good luck trying to figure out what anything does at this point.
-A lot of gameplay elements are questionably balanced and don't seem to serve a function at this time. For example, there is a medic class but there isn't really a tangible purpose to healing your teammates as everyone is very dispersed around the map- and it's really difficult to land the healing device (?) anyways. 
-Some QoL stuff is missing, including what is mentioned above. You can't exit out of a match in the pre-game lobby, and the pre-round timer is too long.
-Some of the maps are not very good. The crash site one invites a lot of pot shots from across the map and a single choke point (a choke point in space! can you believe that?) contains a lot of the fighting.
-Engagement distances are kinda funky as CQC is rare- it's weird to figure out where the shotguns and SMGs will be effective compared to longer-distance weapons.
-For some people, the unlocked axes of movement could probably cause motion sickness.
-Some aspects of the movement are questionable- the landed state is clunky to move to and from, and the momentum brake isn't so useful when you can stop as is. Stick to the grapple for now.
-The tutorials are adequate but leave out lots of helpful info. See above regarding the lack of info in menus.
-The game desperately needs a region lock, and maybe more servers. I am playing against China/SEA players with 300+ ping on a regular basis.


NEUTRAL:
-A lot of the cosmetics in the game so far are directed towards a Chinese audience. Expect a lot of the items ingame right now to seem a bit strange out of context.
-I have heard some reservations from others about the Tencent anticheat but I would wager Tencent has as much data from me as Denuvo and EAC at this point. Download at your peril!!!

OVERALL:

The game is not anywhere near a finished state, which is to be expected in Early Access. I am still really excited to see Boundary improve over time, and I think it has the bones of a very solid, high skill gap, beloved competitive/casual FPS. The developers will undoubtedly encounter rampant sinophobia in a western audience and the challenge will be to warm people up to the unusual concept of space combat, but even in an early state, I can see a lot of love and polish in Boundary. 


Verdict: Maybe wait awhile to purchase as the game is pretty unpolished on Day 1. The price is more than reasonable for what's on offer at $25. I will come back to update this review as the game changes.

The game is not fun. Simple as that.

Combat is as slow as watching grass grow, it feels as if the last 10 years of TRPGs didn't happen or the developers lived under a rock during all that time. But for me, the biggest offender, is the lack of consistency in the world's mechanics.

Stole an apple in this farm? Guess what, the rest of the ENTIRE province now suspects you... for some reason.
See these two boars there? Guess what! They become 7 when you enter combat!
See this battle where you can take sides? Yes, each side has 6 warriors according to the screen! But guess what! When you choose a side and fight the other, your side only get's 2 ally soldiers and the other side gets 7!! 
Oh, I see you have a warband of soldiers? Guess what! This group of 3 peasants can kill them with pitchforks!
See that group of refugees with a horse pulling on a cart? Guess what! You beat them and you get not the horse nor the cart!!


This type of game needs to follow consistent mechanics and visuals to provide the player with realistic important information, information that makes them do the best thing, not trick them into spending materials and medicine curing the warband with little to no gain from fighting 3 peasants armed with sticks and pitchforks, or having the entire province know that they are criminals immediately after taking an apple out of a barrel in some backwater shed...

This game promised a true warband experience, what I got was some arcade attempt at a game from 15 years ago... and not of the good ones on that matter...

Photon Engineer scratches a very specific and persistent itch. The same itch that its peers like Portal, Talos Principal, and The Witness aim to satisfy. While the inspiration from those games is definitely felt, Photon Engineer definitely distinguishes itself and presents a unique and engaging first-person puzzle experience. The setting and style of the game pops with a spacy color palette almost reminiscent of No Man’s Sky. The music choice is pleasing, ranging from peppy to soothing. The overarching plot narrative might be a tad weak, but that only serves as a backdrop for what really matters: the puzzles. There’s something deeply satisfying about freely floating around a puzzle room deciding where to place your precious few mirrors to solve a laser reflection puzzle that doesn’t quite seem to add up. When you do find the solution however, the satisfaction of that “aha” moment is so worth it. Some of the solutions I’ve discovered so far were hard-won but very clever – they always make sense in retrospect, and I’ve yet to come across a solution that felt “unfair.” The laser puzzles are broken up with some sliding tile puzzles as well, which can be deceptively devious for their simple appearances. The two styles of puzzles are staggered such that neither one will become stale or leave you fatigued. The pacing and teaching (environmentally, mostly) in the game is quite good, with only a couple of instances leaving me scratching my head about a game mechanic (an issue that the dev is actively improving). But overall Photon Engineer has been a very satisfying adventure and a substantial brain workout for me. I’m about 16 rooms deep in the game so far, and I’m looking forward to seeing where it goes from here!

I'm impressed with the beautifully rendered backgrounds and thoroughly enjoying the story so far. However, to enhance the immersion of being in the environments, I believe some movement would be beneficial. The interactive dialogue with the characters is a standout feature, making it feel like you're truly there with them.

To further improve the experience, it would be helpful if there were an autodialogue option on a timer, based on the conversations. The current left-click interaction is limiting. Additionally, implementing more colour on the UI and adding keyboard shortcuts such as 1, 2, 3 to select tone options would be a helpful addition.

Overall, the character building is great due to the good writing and dialog options the decision-making yields satisfying results. The game is fun and engaging.

"Road to Devadatta" es un juego de puzzles muy bien diseñado y pensado. Desde el principio, me cautivó la atmósfera y la ambientación del juego, que tiene lugar en un sitio misterioso (que para mi es el antiguo reino indio de Magadha) donde la jugabilidad y la historia se desarrollan en torno a la búsqueda de tu familiar.

La música y los gráficos son bastante buenos, con un estilo visual y sonoro que realmente te sumerge en el mundo del juego. La música es tranquila y relajante, pero a la vez emocionante y te mantiene en tensión mientras exploras el mundo del juego. 

En resumen, "Road to Devadatta" es un juego de Puzzles e intriga  muy bien diseñado y pensado, con desafiantes rompecabezas y una cautivadora historia. Si te gustan los juegos de aventuras y puzzles, definitivamente deberías darle una oportunidad a "Road to Devadatta"

Definitely not as bad as people make it out to be, yes, your starting cards are trash, and your starting tribe might not be for you, but it's really not that difficult to grind out a couple runs to unlock some good cards. Now the RNG and difficult fights, the #1 complaint of this game, they are heavily RNG dependent with your starting cards, but do a few runs and get better starting cards, I assure you, you'll get past the first fight no problem. Next up is synergies, and just because one card does something with health in it's description, doesn't mean that another card with health in it's description will synergize well.

All that being said, you have to play it to get good at it, and you have to play it to see the interesting cards and conditions. You can't just boot it up and be good at it, that's not the point of a roguelike-deckbuilder, let alone a roguelike.

In interest of full disclosure, I was predisposed to disliking this game knowing this was the reason Undergrad Steve handed off writing duties on CK to a couple of hacks. That being said, I really like CK so I knew he could make a decent game and that was enough to convince me to spend the money to give the game a chance. And now, having given the game a chance, my review:

1) Technically the game is fine with the notable exception of the sex scene that wasn't because when I clicked on Yes for manual control, it went by so quickly (and I don't mean the scene was short. I mean it was like somebody hit fast forward and the pages zipped by) that it was basically over before it started. A bit like losing your virginity. 

2) The graphics are fine. Nothing much to say one way or the other. 

3) The writing. This game tries to be serious and funny and doesn't succeed at either one. The MC is whiny and inept, but can suddenly transform into super smooth once you figure out the secret formula (and you will because it's a trope, and a bad one at that).  Your friends seem to exist for no reason other than to further highlight said ineptitude. Most AVNs, or at least the ones I've played, are mindless lighthearted sex romps. Some actually have a little bit of a plot that works in between sex scenes. Some have the potential for a good plot depending on how it develops. Unscripted is none of these. It aims for clever and winds up at contrived. 

Final word: It might be your cup of tea, but for me, Unscripted is Refunded.

This review will cover both volumes of the collection. I am reviewing as a newcomer to the series.

I'm going to start by going over the part that isn't the games themselves: The main menu stuff. Right off the bat you're introduced to a fully voice acted Mega Man.exe who will greet you. There does not appear to be any sort of subtitles option in the release version of the collections, so if you switch the language to one you don't understand you might not get the full benefit of the change in voice actor. Mega Man will greet you every time you boot up the game, and from what I have heard he will even sometimes have different things to say based on the time of day. There's an interact button if you want to make him talk, although the pool of things he has to say doesn't appear to be very large. I so far cannot confirm whether he gains more things to say as you progress in the games. He's overall nothing too complex, but he's a harmless inclusion. If you want him to be quiet, you can also just simply mute him. Pre-orders received cosmetic skins for him, they do nothing other than change his appearance slightly and give him some minor new dialogue. They do not apply to the in-game look, only the main menu.

In regards to other main menu features, it's comparable to the Zero/ZX collection released in 2020. Unlike collections prior to Zero/ZX, there doesn't appear to be any merchandise you can look at or trailers to watch. There's an option to download battle chips, which appears to only work once per save file per game. Volume 2 seems to have a lot more right off the bat. Depending on which volume you're playing at the moment you can listen to the various music from each game and even set one to play as the main menu music, and you have a gallery of artwork based on the games in the volume you're currently in.

As for the games themselves, a noteworthy change compared to previous collections is that entering the collection settings menu doesn't pause the in-game music. I don't really know anything about the content compared to the original releases, but I do know that there's a new font being used for text. There's a filter you can toggle on and off, though the CRT filter of previous collections is missing. It's not really missed in my opinion. With the filter on, there appears to still be stray elements here and there that remain unfiltered, and with the filter off there's still some things that are smoothed out such as certain text elements. It's generally not a big deal, though if you prefer the filter on for some reason you might be annoyed by how many pixels are still visible.

Like previous collections you can choose a border to occupy the space outside of the original aspect ratio. Noteworthy however is the apparent lack of an option to disable borders entirely. If you like having black borders surrounding your retro games instead of stylized artwork, that sadly doesn't seem to be possible here as far as I can tell. You can also choose what size to display the game at on screen. There's small, medium, large, and largest. Largest is as close to full screen as you can get. Testing at 1080p appears to preserve pixel scaling regardless of in-game screen size settings, so you don't have to worry about any misshapen pixels. However, I have heard reports of alternative monitor resolutions not producing perfect pixel scaling. This issue does generally seem to be easier to solve than previous collections however.

A noteworthy inclusion is the new Buster Max mode. This can be toggled both while you are on the main menu and in the collection settings menu in-game at any time. It changes your standard buster attack to do 100 points of damage, trivializing encounters. You can use this as a sort of easy mode, as a way to speed up grinding, or just generally as you see fit. The collection does not punish you for using this in any way, even in regards to achievement collection. It's up to you to decide whether you want to use it or not.

Unfortunately as a newcomer to the series, I don't have much to comment on regarding content inclusions for each game. My understanding is that almost all of the content for each game is here including previously Japanese exclusive content, however my knowledge is limited to the pre-release marketing as I have never played these games before now. I am aware of a new online component regarding trading/battling with other players, but I have not used this feature yet personally.

Overall, the collection doesn't seem to disappoint. It's exactly what it seems to be, and has pretty much everything you could want from such a collection. I'd recommend saving up for the bundle with both volumes and/or waiting for a sale. While I do feel as though the content offered here is worth the release price, I also understand that many people might not be able to afford it at that price. That's okay, don't feel pressured to impulse buy here if it's looking like a bit much for you.

Besides the stupid Denuvo DRM, the game runs pretty smooth with no issues. 

Here you have a collection of battle network games from 1-3, and it seems like the trophys are linked for all 3 games instead of it separately... I'm personally going for a 100% completion which means I have to play it more than once. 

The menus are clean and simple as you are greeted with a Modren 3D model of Megan.exe with the original voice actor from the anime... There is different language options and changing your language does change the logos of the games which is cool but it's still the same game don't be confused that it's some "different version" or anything just because of the logo change for another language. 

In terms of gameplay there isn't anything new, it's basically the same gameplay from the GBA games.

Was is new however is buster MAX mode that allows you to do 100x the damage of your normal buster shot, which is EXTREMELY helpful especially for the first game that doesn't have an escape button.... I don't think I have to remind everyone here how much of a labyrinth structure MESS the first game's internet areas are... And because they are a mess you keep running into enemies that without the escape chip your forced to fight, every, single, TIME... But thanks to Buster MAX mode you can make quick work of this mess. It also doesn't effect trophys, so go ahead and use it if you get stuck, it makes grinding for chips and zennys easier too. 

Extra features include the exclusive battle network Japanese only chips that you can immediately download and use at the start of the game.... they are very overpowered in the early game but if you think you feel guilty about using them early don't..... these games spike up in difficulty. There is also the Japanese only 499 patch cards they added but those are separate from these battle chips and you won't be able to use those until Mega Man Battle Network 4 which is in collection 2. 

Capcom also added online fighting and online trading to all the games, I haven't tested these features yet as it's still pretty early for people to be using it. 

There is a HD filter that makes it less pixelated, in my opinion it looks fine and does make it easier on the eyes but that's just me. 

You can also have different custom borders, which is a neat little addition. 

And then you have the usual MegaMan Collection stuff with the art galleries and music players.... You can actually run as specific music piece to play as your main menu theme though so that's nice. 

Overall your getting a lot of bang for your buck here, definitely recommend getting it.

I'm not gonna recommend this game. I'm sure people will enjoy it, but for a fully released game, I don't believe there is enough content here to justify its $10 pre-sale price tag. As much as I like the concept, I believe it is held back by a few factors: 
1. The weapon variety isn't fleshed out enough. I think that 4 weapons is good, but the weapons themselves (besides the rocket launcher) didn't bring me to try different playstyles. The minigun is essentially a faster firing pistol, and the shotgun is typically the best gun for most situations.
2. Level design. Aside from a few levels, they mostly play the same. All trucks are the same size, all cars are cars, It would've been cool to use bits of the environment more as a way to navigate. The enemy placement is another thing, and is noticed towards the end especially. They tend to be spread out or condensed, but the AI doesn't like the latter so they tend to trickle towards you unless you rush in.
3. Movement. The movement is fine, and I don't want to compare this to ultrakill too much, but for a game that is all about fast paced movement, it is really difficult to keep up momentum. The only truly fast way of moving is the grapplehook, which stops you at its point. Dashing out of it still loses that momentum. It would have been nice if movement focused on that momentum that surges you forward, since the game forces you to move ahead.
4. Enemies. There is little enemy variety. When combined with weird placement, it feels as though there are no challenges. In my game, the #1 reason I died was the tunnel level, where signs and pipes instakill you. They also kill all of the enemies, so it just becomes "run forward and dodge." It would have been nice to see enemies have to be taken out in different ways. Melee enemies are always killed in a kick, but what if they could block it or counter? I never really felt endangered in my time to just run into a group of melee guys and kick them. 
5. Time. It took me 39 minutes to beat the "main game." And while yes, there is infinite mode, that is just not for me. I kept expecting as I played through the game that there would be some big moment, something that would test my skills toward the end. Instead, it tests whether you remember to use your grappling hook. It left a sour taste in my mouth. 

To Conclude, it's not a bad game, but because of the factors I mentioned above, I cannot recommend it in its current state. As much as I dislike early access, this game should be labeled it. It doesn't feel like a fully released game, with nominative amount of content for its price. This game ends with a cliffhanger stating that it will be continued, but that isn't enough for me to recommend it. Just because I do not recommend it does not mean it is a bad game, there is probably something there for people, but not for me. 

P.S. for the devs
If you want to improve this game, please prove that it is not a unity asset flip by continuing development. Go beyond being a copy of the clustertruck formula. There's a lot more I could say, but I'll just leave as this: prove me wrong.
It is fun and creative game! I can recomend it, if you like Serious Sam or Painkiller style games.

Remake > Original

Yep, you read that right. The remake of the classic SH game The Awakened is fantastic and the expanded storyline alongside the the side cases (which are quite a lot compared to what I expected) make it so much better than the original. I am a proud backer of the kickstarter campaign for this project. I have no regrets. It was worth it.

The story is almost the same, some minor changes here and there. It was rewritten to fit in the new timeline. There are some references to Chapter One but if you're a new player, don't worry. You can play it as a standalone game. You are in for a real treat !

The characters, what can I say ? The chemistry between the new friends-to-be Holmes and Watson is on point. This journey tests their relationship to the maximum.

The music is splendid. It makes the experience even more immersive. The dark atmoshpere of the game is *chef's kiss*.

The gameplay mechanics are the same as Chapter One's with some little differences. There is the mind palace (which is different from the previous games), deductions, pin an evidence to search for more clues, interact with people, you can change Holmes and Watson's clother.

The graphics are great, the game ran very smoothly. The team did a great job in optimizing it.

Frogwares deserves all the praise and our respect for what they've done. Delivering a game in such tough times and in so little time...it's incredible. The game was announced in July 2022 and now in April 2023 we are playing it. Frogwares, I take my hat off before you ! Well done !

TLDR: An excellent roguelike featuring turn-based tactical combat in the style of XCOM that mixes in elements from Darkest Dungeon (Eg. Camping Skills). I would recommend Shardpunk: Verminfall to anyone that enjoys or is looking to get into this particular genre of games - especially at this price point. 

Having just finished my first successful run on normal, which I binged over the course of 9 hours, I have to say that it's quite the compact yet fairly polished experience. The core combat loop is extremely enjoyable and is fairly similar to XCOM in this regards, where good positioning and target priority is highly rewarded. This is complimented by an excellent soundscape and a banger OST, which creates a wonderful atmosphere of perpetual tension — which really comes to forefront in the lulls between combat encounters. 

The game, much to my surprise, also has an excellent tutorial stage. To someone who is new to the genre, it does a good job of bringing the player up to speed on the key game systems and guiding them on how they actually work in practice by introducing important complexities - such as how Weapon Heat interacts with Overwatch. As such, the tutorial is quite useful for veterans of the genre as well, as it clearly explains and demonstrates mechanics which either iterate on the X-COM formula or a simply brand new (Ohhh Looting Spree my beloved)

Whilst I could go on at length about how I enjoyed all these iterations/additions to the X-COM formula, the sheer excitement and/or panic that I experienced when I interacted with them for the first-time is something I highly recommend that you experience yourself. 

Just wanted to close out this review by thanking Splattercatgaming for featuring this game on their channel, as I would have never have stumbled across this game myself.
Fantastic gameplay and amazing racing mechanics!

This game is very difficult, but it is not nearly as bad as other reviews make it out to be. It forces you to think in new ways, which if you have 1,000+ hours in StS, will certainly be a struggle. You are going to lose a lot when you first start out, but that is part of the game's progression. As you progress through runs and complete quests, you unlock more upgrades, cards, tribes, and equipment which can make the next run easier, and that progression goes on until you reach a comfortable spot. Definitely check the game out as it has a fun art-style and interesting combat mechanics that make it stand-out amongst the plethora of roguelike deckbuilders. Just don't go in expecting to win your first, or even your 20th run, because you will not.

Wildfrost is a good roguelike deck builder. If you like roguelike deck builders give this a try. 
At times it does feel like you are banging your head against a stone wall but sooner or later it does crack. In order to find the crack you have to learn the game and the most important thing to learn is patience. I can't tell you how many runs I've thrown away because I quickly played the card I had planned and didn't see an enemy was going to act or some other small detail that ended up killing someone. My first completed run felt like a true accomplishment due to the difficulty of this game. It does feel a little on the short side but hopefully there will be more content in the future.

Lots of fun! Love the art style, love the general vibe of the game, love the gameplay. As for what seems to have become the elephant in the room, the challenge level, it's certainly made me think, but I haven't had anywhere near the negative experience that a lot of others seem to have. I've won several times and gotten the true ending (at least what seems to be the true ending) and I haven't run into anything that seemed insurmountable along the way. I do have a lot of experience with Slay the Spire, Monster Train, and such going in (as well as Dungeon Beneath, which has positioning mechanics a lot like this game) so maybe that's the difference, but on the whole I've found it a fun but not at all overwhelming challenge.

Really difficult but extremely satisfying. Each encounter really tests your game knowledge and decision making but since it's a card game you can take it slow and analyze the board for as long as you need (seriously guys, I see so many players rush when there's literally no timer, slow down and you'll find victory much much more achievable). That being said, the game is very difficult, enemies start to ramp up fast, you can get RNGd charms (I got bread, chucklefish, and scrap in a row while playing shademancers), and they make you learn things the hard way. After beating the game in normal mode a number of times I finally tried the bell challenges and actually beat all the challenges in succession (Berry builds OP). Sadly there's no more challenges after that apart from the daily runs. Overall I'd give it an 8/10, hoping future updates improve the game further by adding more content and making the base difficulty easier while also adding higher difficulty. Oh and the art is hella cute, well done Gazi.

I like this game!
It isn't inventing the wheel, but it isn't pretending to. On the other hand it's very polished and cozy!

I appreciate it incorporating flavor and world into each run.

I like the progression but the mastery curve is very steep, I at least havn't found a way to consistently get past world 2.

Art and music are amazing, and despite the "serviceable" gameplay they make the game still worth playing. However, do remember by purchasing you're directly supporting Chucklefish, who are an exploitative and abusive company.

What's wrong with the gameplay? I'm an A20H Slay the Spire player, and because I was expecting this to be a contender to StS, I'm going to judge it relative to that. If you're not looking for a StS-like experience, then take the below with a grain of salt. I also only played for 2 hours, so I can't comment on how the game changes as you unlock more items.

In general, the most disappointing part of the experience was the lack of agency. I felt that playing only one card per turn significantly reduced the sense of control, despite turns being more numerous and shorter than StS. Being able to also move units does not add much to the decision space, as it's usually obvious what the best positioning is.

Outside of combat, the pathing options are reduced (Monster Train style), and there is a complete lack of events - your choice are usually card removal, gold, a shop, a card or a charm.  

From the few relics I saw, these appear to be far less interesting than other deckbuilders. The only relics I saw in my gametime affected card draw/other uninteresting things. There are also no card upgrades, but you can add effects to cards using charms.

All of this made me question the long term replayability of the game, as there simply isn't enough variation in the gameplay, or enough interesting decisions to make, for me to see myself putting even 50+ hours into this. Not to mention the lack of ascensions, beyond what I hear is simply adding random charms to enemies, which is a very lazy way to scale difficulty.

And finally, be warned that the game *is* reasonably difficult, but I did beat the first two bosses within my 2hr playtime. The difficulty of the game is a really weird design choice, as the lack of agency (and the cute artwork) really make you expect to be able to breeze through, and that's clear from the negative reviews the game is getting. This game really needs to decide who its core audience is, because right now it's appealing to neither the die-hard deckbuilder fans nor the casual players.

I really enjoy this game. art is great and the random rng is actually fun with forcing you to make interesting mixes of comps and strats. The balance obviously seems a little off for casual play because there is a lot going on per turn as well as not paying attention to 1 turn could mean you get wiped. The trinket system is really cool and I would like to see that polished with more options to make your own custom cards in combat more. I think if the enemies were a little less responsive so quickly or reinforcement counter was like a turn longer it might flesh it out more.

Just my opinion. For the hero you start with, maybe add a little more pizzazz to them like with hero options:
--
Better stat hero
--
Hard focus strategy hero
--
more than one status effect
--

Around those options only because, starting with a 3 health range hero with long shot feels pretty bad when your random companion rng isn't a tank. I like the game, difficulty is always weird with people in rouges but it comes with the territory.

Fantastic art. Acceptable music. Great sounds. Mechanics are very solid and manageable. Overall, a really enjoyable rougelite deckbuilder.

HOWEVER, the other reviews are correct in that this game desperately needs a balance pass. Certain builds will work great until you encounter a specific boss. For example, using a thorn/smackback build will always fail against King Moko (a boss that requires you hit them repeatedly and quickly). 

In addition, the mechanic that the final boss uses can easily prevent you from ever winning the game again. On my first (and only) win I had a build that was absolutely insane. Because of that, the final boss is now virtually impossible to beat.

The most innovative, excellent Roguelike deckbuilder. There are so many little details that demonstrate how much the developers polished the game. 

Don't be fooled by people reviewing it negatively. After playing for 10 hours, I found that every death was due to either my own mistakes or bad RNG, which is to be expected in the roguelike genre. Perhaps the cute art style of this game attracts people who should not be playing it, as opposed to games like Dark Souls, FTL, or Into the Breach. 

Looking forward to future updates. 10/10

An immaculately polished jewel of a game. A roguelike deckbuilder game much like Monster Train with a variety of units and cards in a turn based structure. Art direction, Music, and UI all stand out as very polished and considered. Even from the demo, it was evident how much care was put into the game. Seriously, it's crazy to think how this was made by just two people.

(Bear in mind though, it's hard. It looks kid-friendly, but the game does not show mercy. Part of that is just accepting defeat gracefully. It comes with the roguelike genre.)

In any case, I have a feeling I'll be playing this game for a long time.

I liked the game (obviously) but here's my main criticisms:

Because most the game is gated by the skill you need from your grappling hook, you can go almost anywhere from the get go, while most skills afterwards just make your hook easier to use. This is cool for exploration- but in turn you can get super deep into a section of the map just to hit a brick wall requiring a certain item right before the end (looking at you, Lab)

Also expect some bugs- like the item tracker being wrong for one area of the game, or one section of the map where I literally had to glitch through a wall to make it into (still no idea what the intended route for that was)

The story is a bit messy, especially how the end feels rushed together, and the combat in general really isn't that enjoyable. The pistol is the only fun weapon to use, but you spend most the game using the rocket launcher because it comes paired with necessary movement options

And lmao shoutouts to the trinket you get halfway into the game that makes the UI legible, why would that not just be a default thing

The game could use a lot of minor polish, but it's still a solid metroidvania.

Tron: Identity invited me back into the world of Tron after several years away with an immediately intriguing and thought provoking story that I can only relate to the feeling of following a carrot on a stick—in all the good ways! 

The score by Dan Le Sac along with the striking 2D and 3D art illustrated in an incredibly satisfying 3D style (that I can only relate to that of a moving wallpaper) kept me absorbed into the world of Tron, and The Grid, for the duration of my 5-hour playtime.

The story was masterfully written and filled with character and depth that can only be appreciated more with further playthroughs to explore the branching paths that go against our natural instincts. As I believe sometimes, the best stories can be told from the perspective of a character that makes wildly different choices than we ever would in any situation.

The story beats kept me guessing too, with meticulously hand-picked dialogue choices that thankfully rarely, if ever, offered aid or a new perspective on any situation. Without spoiling any story details, Tron: Identity hides consequences within even the most well intended choices, and with an auto-save after every choice. I really felt my characters emotions whenever something didn’t go my way, either due to an immediate branching choice, or one I made earlier. As I am one who likes to always make the right choices in these kind of games, Tron: Identity really challenged that, never giving even the subtlest hint at what the “right” choice is in any situation. They all have consequences in some way or another, even those that you may consider to be the morally right choice. I’d even go so far to say it may be difficult on a second playthrough to get the “best” outcome from every branching path.

A quote from the game that sums up my experience perfectly is “you’ve seen where good intentions can lead”.

That said, the game still needs an actual competitive mode that let's you play a match from beginning to end with the same team. The Gold Standard of VR tactical shooters. It has some of the most clean gunplay I have experienced in VR. I have played alot of Pavlov, contractors, onward, and other random shooters and this one takes the cake for the gunplay. A great balance of sweaty but fun. Siege meets CSGO is the best way to describe it. Full siege gameplay round to round but with buying in between rounds that has you managing your economy, again like CS GO or valorant.  If you have seen Vail VR its not as sweaty as that and with better gunplay but this game is more sweaty than the other shooters I mentioned previously. It is the right balance of fun but challenging. Yes as the other reviews mention it is full of quest kids and it can be really annoying, but that isn't an inherent problem with the game itself, rather the audience. There is a ping system if you feel like muting everyone and you can even use actual tactical  hand signals by resting your fingers on different buttons if you really dont want to hear people. Highly recommend even at full price, I was supposed to just play for a bit but got sucked in for the rest of my night after work when I tried it out.

I'm not usually one to write reviews, but when a relatively small team makes a hidden gem, I need to review it, in the hopes more people will pick the game up so the developers are motivated to keep making more of these games.
Frogwares Sherlock Holmes series has been very hit or miss for me, with the previous title, Chapter One, being a miss in my opinion. The older version of Sherlock Holmes: The Awakened also didn't do it for me. I loved the story, but the game was too janky for me to truly enjoy it. Luckily then, that this remake delivers that same excellent story, expanded upon it, and delivers it with an entertaining gameplay loop for those who enjoy more narrative-driven puzzle adventure games.
Admittedly, the game is fairly easy and straight-forward. It didn't challenge my deductive reasoning skills as much as Sherlock Holmes: Crimes & Punishments did (in my opinion still the best Frogwares Sherlock Holmes game). It's also fairly linear, and the path forward is usually not difficult to figure out. But while the game is easy, it provides just enough of a challenge to never be boring.
The best part of this game is its narrative and presentation. This game oozes atmosphere, and the story is a compelling one. It often expands and improves on the narrative of the old The Awakened game, and even for people who played that version, this game's story will have some interesting surprises in store. Truly, it's one of the best Sherlock Holmes stories to date, and that is including the movies, TV series, and novels. But of course this game isn't just about Sherlock, it's also about the Cthulhu Mythos, and it doesn't disappoint in that area either. If you're looking for a great Lovecraftian story, this game has what you're looking for.
I'm excited to see what the future holds for this iteration of Sherlock Holmes and John Watson. I hope Frogwares will remake Sherlock Holmes: vs Jack the Ripper next.

I don't normally post reviews but I felt like I had to because people are being incredibly unfair. Yes, the game is hard, but the challenge is what makes finding a way through that much more rewarding! Learning what works and what doesn't is part of the fun and the large card pool gives lots of room to try new strategies.

The game is fantastic, I sunk many hours in since purchase. It shows how fun it is. The game is straightforward with it's mechanics, and the cards are explained really well. There are 3 full unique factions that are easily unlockable right now. The art style and music are wonderful and add to the experience. The charms are my favorite part of the game, they add great synergies and give you the ability to craft unique cards!

Game is challenging enough to feel rewarding to win. And the progression of the game is exciting. Getting to fight against your own squad to win is ridiculous, hilarious, and can be a fun challenge.

Things that could be improved are adding even more variety. If you enjoy the game a lot at the release, some things can get a bit repetitive. But it's understandable at it's current state of the game. Also, I don't really like the pet mechanic (you get a first companion of your choice), because companion choices are very limited. I wish the first companion was also randomized after you choose your leader. Lastly, would be great to see 3 leaders of each faction as a choice. Because once you unlock all the factions, you get a randomized leader per faction, which can be limiting if you really enjoy playing only one of them. I felt much better about it before I unlocked factions, because I could choose 3 different leaders from starting faction. Other than that, it's a great game that I really recommend, and I hope it will only get better. 

This is my first review of the game ever. I can't help but notice lots of negative reviews. I think people forget how challenging roguelites can be. I do see the frustration element where one positioning mistake could quickly end your run. However, currently, I find the game well-balanced, and full of opportunities to explore broken synergies with companions, cards, and charms.

A better Lovecraftian tale than most.

[i]The Awakened[/i] tackles the collision between rationality and the irrational, and pits the man of deduction and reason against those things that destroy you when you come to know them. It's a great blueprint for a story, but the execution of such a high concept is difficult for even the best storytellers. Focusing in on this angle, on Sherlock Holmes' descent into madness as he tries to unravel his first big case alongside Watson, is the strongpoint of this remake; I haven't played the original but I feel like it wasn't an element there. The characters are endearing and the performances strong enough to sell their relationship - another improvement, as I understand - over the older series of games.

It's clear that Frogwares have evolved their craft, both that of telling Lovecraftian stories and of making Holmes games. With this one, they understand that they key to selling cosmic horror is not to portray it directly (as they did in the ambitious, but flawed [i]Sinking City[/i] - a game I rather loved, for all its faults). The key is to dance around the edges, revealing the minimal amount possible, skirting the line between mundane human cruelty and supernatural evil, until the characters (and hopefully the audience) start jumping at shadows. Holmes [i]can't[/i] be allowed to be certain either way if he's sane or mad, and the narrative sustains that ambiguity well.

The problems, I'd say, are the same ones Frogwares always has. The standardized investigation gameplay yields to easily to brute-force play, and the concept of the game deserved a grander budget and more time. It feels, at least, like the game could have benefited from a few more connective scenes here and there, an earlier setup for the final villain and more polished presentation of certain gameplay elements (like the shooting segments), so that it feels more natural and less on-rails. However, given that this game was made in the middle of a warzone, it's a stunning accomplishment as it stands.

I think the madness sections deserve special consideration. Narratively, they're great breaks in the game's pacing and are very good at setting up a sinister, unnerving atmosphere. I also love their game design. Very clearly they function with rules so violent and obscure that they might as well be madness (even though they *are* rules). That's a pretty elegant representation of the kind of stuff Lovecraft was talking about. They were really good sections and I only wish they had been better spread throughout the game. Maybe shorter, and added in a few more spots.

In the future I would like to see more involved and complicated deduction mechanics and better setup and characterization for supporting characters. Making the many outfits in the game actually relevant to the gameplay (as they were in [i]Chapter One[/i]) would also be nice. And, also, Frogwares, *please* go through one of these games without referencing Moriarty. We get it. He's out there. He even has an anime now. Stop trying to make him into an Marvel arch-villain.

I was very happy to support and play this game. I may have been critical in my review but it's still Frogwares at their finest. I look forward to seeing what other games they make when this war is over.

Right. I have a lot positive to say, and very little negative. Like, no negatives at all. And for reference, I did 2 playthroughs for testing on both the Steam Deck and standard Windows PC, and I can safely say this is one of the most enjoyable games I have played in a while. It absolutely doesn't waste your time, and absolutely rewards replays. I will cover what I enjoyed, cause there's nothing I disliked, and then talk about some wee bugs I encountered, which weren't game breaking or anything, so they weren't bad... at all, really. And also in the case of Steam Deck, it could be down to the preset Proton it uses causing issues.

So what are the positives?
-Amazing music
-Fun characters. I am british, and the game is british, so it's a no brainer that I enjoyed the humour that comes from the characters. I absolutely appreciated the design of the killer too
-Amazing artstyle and colour scheme
-The easter egg(s) and references to pop culture were enjoyable to find and understand
-The game is only about 4 hours long per playthrough, which is short and sweet, and something I appreciate alot more as I grow older
-Just play the game, you'll understand more fully. It's absolutely worth every playthrough.

You mentioned issues with the game?!?!!??!?
Barely, but yes, which is absolutely why I did two playthroughs, just to see what the difference between Steam Deck and my laptop were.....but there still weren't alot of issues, either. Pretty much all it comes down to is:
-Steam Deck had some flickering textures, some minor performance stutters, but only really affected my experience for a few seconds everytime it happened. I played on Handheld at 60hz, but didn't test docked because I'm too lazy to plug it in again. But if you only have a Steam Deck, you won't have any real issues with it on there, and the trackpads will also be very helpful in your adventure, and you have to be absolutely mindful of Proton, especially when the game is unsupported, there is no real telling what exactly will happen with the game, so do keep that in mind
-Game specific...... I found a way to glitch deeper beside a locker with the door in the security room by just walking into it while it was opening up, and moving the camera around a bit to get yourself fully lodged in there. But literally all you have to do to get out is close the door and it'll send you flying to the other side of the room. I don't even see it as an issue, it's quite entertaining to do. I couldn't find any issues the Steam Deck didn't have already, so both experiences are absolutely amazing from the getgo.

So overall?
I've never been so hooked on a game in my life, and I really do mean that. Especially because of the length of the game, I couldn't help but just continue playing till the end, and even to 100% every achievement. The environment is so pretty to look at, you can pet the dog and enjoy a nifty 4 hour tale about a pig killer doing killer things. Not much else to say, apart from what was already in the bullet points..... ALTHOUGH, do not play with the VHS filter off. The flickering becomes much more of a problem with it off, and even shows off unique flickering to the filter being off, which I suppose the VHS filter is able to hide. It definitely ruins the vibe of the game, but I totally get why such a feature is implemented, and I'm not gonna put that as a negative for it. It's helpful for those that need it, but at least currently, it's quite hard to look at. But otherwise, the game is amazing, and you should absolutely play it now.

My rig is an i9, 32 gb ram and 3070; I shouldn't have graphical issues especially on an old game like this. Lack of a 'fast' mode (common in all emulators) is also disappointing.

I'm hoping that the game plays well on the steam deck, otherwise I'll likely be requesting a refund. Super dissapointing as I've been waiting for this since it was announced, and hoping for it for over a decade. This was my favorite GB game as a kid

Its exactly what it claims to be: Its a legacy collection of the MMBN games. Its not a remaster, its not a remake, its all of the games in two packages. They give you extra goodies like artwork, music player, and other things, but please don't go into this assuming its going to be some upgraded reboot with crazy HD features. They never promised that. If you enjoyed MMBN (I definitely did), you'll enjoy this. If you didn't like the MMBN games, you wont enjoy this, Also, its best to play this game with controller. Some people complained about the lack of remappable controls, but I maybe I'm too much of a causal to care. I play most games with controller anyways, especially 2D games. 

The ONLY thing that I don't like about this collection is the Buster Max mode. Its too OP of a option and I hate having the option to take an easy route in games. Id rather the temptation not be there, But considering that its an optional option (Im using that word "option" as if I have no other word options), I'm going to keep it turned off. Buster Max will take away the fun of the game for me, but its good for if you revisit areas that you already beat and want to look for any loot you missed without dealing with battles. You also don't want to use Buster Max if you plan on playing online unless you are already a master at the game, otherwise, you wont understand the mechanics of the game and all of the cards and your skills are going to atrophy. You will get deleted like an "I'm sorry" text to your ex. 

Overall: Get it! Its really fun! But try not to use Buster Max except for grinding. Play the game the way it was originally meant to be played and you'll have a blasty blast. :)

I played the demo for Rusted Moss and was sold on it very quickly, an action platformer built around a grappling hook sounds great, and the combat sections mostly are. Slingshotting around arenas to dodge bullets and fight bosses is satisfying, while the dedicated platforming sections were less enjoyable. The grappling hook functions like elastic and these spaces play around a lot with the physics, but many ask for some hyper precise movement that is difficult to nail down consistently with how inherently chaotic such freeform mobility can be, there is little room for error in this basic traversal ultimately making it feel like a frustrating test of patience. I spent large chunks of time within singular rooms wrestling with the grapple trying to get it to behave just the way I needed it to in order to progress, sitting on the edge of my seat trying not to die and be sent rooms and rooms back to the checkpoint, which is not something I've ever experienced in a physics based platformer before. The pacing of upgrades is also incredibly odd, within the first thirty to forty-five minutes I picked up the basic grappling hook and a high jump, and those were the only movement upgrades I had received up until my final half hour. Everything in-between was either a passive effect or a weapon I could only find a niche use for. It was very refreshing to see a new mechanic and potentially loosen up some of the tighter platforming areas, but it was immediately made irrelevant by the next area where I was in zero gravity and at the whims of hazards that are made to force the player in different directions. I really wanted to like Rusted Moss, but I felt like I never got a good handle on the controls or stopped fighting with the game, and my aggravation led me to dropping it close to the finish line. I think I would get more enjoyment out of watching speedruns than actually playing it.

I love this game! It has a really cute art style and tons of charm. There are plenty of fun and workable synergies, and a lot of neat unlocks. I'm writing this review because I really enjoy this game and I'm deeply saddened to see so many negative reviews, especially when I disagree with their theses.

A lot of the negative reviews focus on game balance, and RNG.
To preface, I've played both demo cycles of this game, and have currently won two runs. (9 hrs of playtime)
I think it would definitely be good if some cards got re-balance love, but most cards are very obviously good, or not so good. This is very normal for rogue-like deckbuilders! Some tools are bad, unless you're already severely lacking in them.
This game isn't necessarily easy, despite the art style, and you should not necessarily win every run!

I believe a lot of players are either not thinking through their turns properly, or are not used to the style of gameplay this game revolves around (Each unit has a turn timer until it triggers). The rng in this game is sometimes punishing (as is the nature of rogue-likes), but it never feels unfair. If your deck is based around abusing a single mechanic, prepare to lose if you find yourself against a horde of enemies built to counter it! Building decks with tools to counter your counters is essential.

I think the game could benefit from some ui quality of life changes, (hovering over enemy charms and being able to see their effects, undoing held cards is sometimes finicky), but overall this game is amazing. I highly recommend it.
Game is good, polished fully complete fun rogue like being released. Difficulty can be patched if it is a legitimate issue. It is a good game.

Art style, music, and gameplay is phenomenal. The difficulty feels it needs to be balanced but I might also just be bad at games. Only quality of life thing as I'm writing this is I feel can be fixed is when you fail a run there is a button that exits to desktop and if playing with controller that's the default option selected. Because of this its way too easy to accidentally close out of the game. It'd be better if the button was for exiting to main menu.

Criticism noted can all be attributed to the game launching two days ago and needs to be minorly balanced. Otherwise it's a fantastic game with amazing gameplay that I cannot recommend enough

Okay, listen, I've been playing the Battle Network games for a little over a decade now, and I thought I'd basically experienced the peak version of Battle Network 5 with the Nintendo DS release, known as Double Team DS. I have my copies of BN3, 4, 5, and 6 on GBA as well, and even got the Bass icon on my BN5 save file so I could access Bass Cross on the DS version AND send over whatever the heck kind of folder I wanted to build from the GBA version of 5 to the DS one.

Let me tell you that all of that does not even compare to how shwacked the mod cards are for BN5 alone. Holy moly, I loaded up FireMan's card immediately because I love that guy and I get a Fire Arm Charge Shot AND a Heat Elemental affinity, complete with a new super rad color scheme to boot. I usually don't bother to get the Black Bomb R from the Purple Mystery Data in ACDC 2 until I've at least got the Hot Body chips at my disposal, but with the Fire Arm charge shot, I made that the first thing I beelined for in this new save file. It is BUSTED this early on AND there's a mod card section for items. Guess what's among them? BLACK BOMB Z. I have two, fucking TWO Black Bombs in my folder and I haven't even put ProtoMan in his place yet.

This is the most cathartic run of Battle Network 5 I've ever done and I have so many different ways I can now modify my play style. I loaded up a card with the Status Bug for a free 50/50 shot at either a temporary buff or debuff, which is normally something I have to bug my Navi Cust for with more than four colors, but now I just have that! I had experience with Mega Man Zero 3's mod cards before thanks to the Zero Collection on DS and the Zero/ZX Legacy Collection, but those pale in comparison to what's offered for the Battle Network games. Oh my god. I'm already making plans for my next Dark Soul playthrough of Team Colonel after I finish my current playthrough of Team ProtoMan.

Good lord, this is a whole new way to play some of my favorite RPGs of all time. I've already been juggling these games for roughly a year now on my DS, as the combat's so consistently satisfying to me that it never gets old or leads to burnout, but this pair of collections has reignited my passion for experimenting with loads of different folders and strategies. I haven't felt this close to combat nirvana since the first time I used the different Mod Codes in Battle Network 3's Navi Customizer all those years ago. KTEIUE2D, the Super Armor code, still remains embedded in my mind and I'm convinced it will remain there until the day I die.

So yeah, the collections fucking own. Play Battle Network 2, 3, or 6 as a starting point and go from there. 1 and 4 are super rough and I'd recommend at least having a foothold in the series before attempting them. 5's probably the hardest one, so while I love it to death, I can see it being a bit much for newcomers at first. Still damn good though. Absolutely give 5 a shot. God, I love Battle Network so much. AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

P.S. If anyone's interested in doing some netbattling and/or trading together, I'm down for that! I've been wanting to finally experience the PVP side of these games for years!

I have not completed Rusted Moss yet, but I plan on getting further into it. So far, I am enjoying it but I do have some criticisms to lay out. 

What I enjoy about the game is the fast-paced action where you have to be careful how you proceed or the enemies will make quick work of you. The areas are very different from each other, and the accompanying music matches well which can be challenging for some games to do. As someone who loves an engaging plot with character development, I didn't find much of that here as the story was more in the background and not interesting enough to focus on. 

Where Rusted Moss lacks the most is in its controls and grappling hook ability. It's fun to be able to swing around and get to places quickly, as I could see professional speed runners putting their skills to the test here. The problem is if you aren't used to the feature it can be difficult to get through some areas. 

I often spent more time in one section trying to swing past some spikes than getting through the stage. It made the game less enjoyable and at times I wanted just to quit and do something else, like write this review to not get tired of being impaled.

I would give Rusted Moss a chance if you have not played it as it is fun, but the difficulty certainly should be modified which I would find hard to pull off since the level design would have to be changed. It's a game that succeeds in making a pixelated platformer that tries to be a Metroidvania, but gets stuck in its own mechanics like the grappling.

I rarely leave reviews especially this early on, but watching the dumpster fire that is the reviews for this game is kind of sad. The claims of bad balance and RNG reliance are just completely out of touch with reality.

Deckbuilders are challenging, the fun is in making interesting decisions and solving complicated situations. This game is no exception.

This game is oozing with charm, and has cool mechanics that sets it apart from others in the genre. It's fun to play and satisfying to win. 

It's challenging but in an engaging way. You'll have to trust me and many other veterans in the genre saying it's not the game that's unfair, you're just bad. But that's okay! Play more, spend a little more time before clicking on things, learn how different systems interact, and enjoy the process of improving!

Game feels great but being a slow paced TPS game, this is a game of "peekaboo", which means everyone and their moms are hiding behind cover and using Third Person view to check for enemies.

Another problem is classes' weapons, in other shooter games, all "classes" have weapons that doesn't make them useless, here some operators just have bad weapons and you can't do a thing with it, there is a reason why Medics and Marksman are never used while in other shooters they're always filled first, their weapons SUCKS, marksman in special, they have no option to change to another main weapon so your best bet is either the VSS or a DMR with high fire rate because most "snipers" don't kill on headshot and because of that, you're always looking for at least 2 shots to kill people.

Some small problems would be progression, like, you need to play a lot with your operator to "level him up" and then unlock passive/talents to bulk him up, you pay an in-game currency for that, I reckon that it should take quite some time (maybe 8~20 hours?) of playtime with an operator to fully unlock him...and then unlock other operators to use their passive on other operators too...in any case, I don't feel like this one is a major problem because it adds progression to the game.

In any case, this game is a hard pass, specially if you're not into TPS shooters, if it were an FPS game then the slow paced combat and the need of awareness would definetely make this a good game, as of now, I can't recommend it to anyone.

Rewind or Die" is a thrilling and gruesome horror game that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. As a fan of Puppet Combo's previous works, I was excited to try out their latest creation and I wasn't disappointed.

The game's retro aesthetic and VHS-style visuals create a truly immersive and nostalgic experience, reminiscent of classic horror films from the 80s and 90s. The gameplay is challenging, but never feels unfair or frustrating, as you navigate through eerie environments and encounter terrifying enemies.

One of the standout features of "Rewind or Die" is its unique "rewind" mechanic, which allows players to go back in time and try again if they meet a gruesome end. This adds an interesting layer of strategy to the game, as you must plan your movements and actions carefully in order to avoid being killed.

The sound design in "Rewind or Die" is also worth mentioning, as it adds to the game's overall atmosphere and sense of dread. The music and sound effects are expertly crafted to create an unsettling and immersive experience.

Overall, "Rewind or Die" is a fantastic horror game that I would highly recommend to fans of the genre, especially those who appreciate Puppet Combo's unique and creative approach to horror gaming. With its retro style, challenging gameplay, and innovative mechanics, "Rewind or Die" is sure to keep you entertained and terrified for hours on end.

Dang, I was excited for this one. The atmosphere and setting is there, but there's a lot that brings it down. I'll do a pros and cons list:

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The setting - Like I said earlier, the level design and visuals are fantastic, definitely up there with the rest of the Torture Star/Puppet Combo games. If anything, it might even take the #1 spot.
    [*]The villain - Not too much to say here as most villains in these games don't get much development past their looks and actions. The pig look is freaky and cool looking, and his sprint animation is pretty scary too.
    [*]The scares - If you're not into random and unnecessary jump scares, this game might annoy you. But they got me good and I enjoyed them, so it's a pro for me.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The music - There is not a lot of music in this game. Not a huge deal, but my biggest issue is with the chase music, which you're going to hear a lot. The heavy metal song itself sounds cool, but it really takes me out of the experience. It's not scary at all, it's only startling because that means you're about to be chased.
    [*]The puzzles - You can turn your brain off for the entire game basically. The most engaging parts of the game were the sudden jump scares and chases. 
    [*]No sense of urgency - I never felt on edge except for one chapter of the game, where the killer is actually roaming around the level. Take Murderhouse or Stay Out Of The House for example, you have to complete puzzles WHILE the killer is actively looking for you, I always felt extremely anxious entering new rooms in those games. The killer, aside from scripted sequences, is no where near you for the majority of this game.

The game felt like it was about to get really good the entire time, and then it just ended. Unfortunate, because I did enjoy my time for a little bit; it just fell super flat.

Ignore the bad reviews talking about bad connection or the game being boring.

A: You can select the regions you want to connect to on the matchmaking tab, it'll take a bit of time before everyone sees this and goes to their respective regions. (side note I want the game to remember what regions I have selected when I reboot it)

Since you're in space, where there is no air, you have have 2 health bars, One is your suit, the more you get hit, the more it will go down but sometimes it will become punctured in which you need to patch it up, which doesn't take long but the more you wait, the more it will drain your second health bar, oxygen, if it runs out then you pass out and die, pretty simple, the only time you have to worry about running out is if your suit is punctured. 

This game is a dream to play, the gun play is pretty cool due to there being nothing quite like it on the market. The zero gravity really flips how you think about recoil and range. Also the physics are very interesting, with your gun's recoil pushing you back certain distances depending on the type of ammo fired. As well as on certain maps you can pressurize rooms which eliminates your oxygen bar while you are in the room, you can also open a door which will launch you out into the map (think of the gravity launchers in Apex Legends).

You can also customize your astronaut which is cool but I wish there were more cosmetics (probably will come with time; side note I really, really want country flags as patches).

Overall its a super unique game and I'm very excited to see what else the developers have in the future.

This isn't the greatest VR port but its not the worst. I did enjoy it though. I had some issues with the hands feeling a little too small but that's probably a me issue. Gun audio is weird. I experienced a few crashes but nothing that really ruined the experience for me. I think the way you change weapons in this game to be a bit tedious but i don't have any good suggestions for that. I would also love the be able to two hand weapons like the magnum. I also found it weird there's no audio settings or in-level pause menu options. Overall rating I'd say is a 6/10. It's fun, kept to the same general idea. I also like that the gun models are different and not shoe-horned into a VR setting. I also like the new levels and level design, shows that y'all actually cared and this wasn't just a cash-grab. It's fun in short burts but not for long sessions. I'd say buy this if you have money to spare.

This game is a blast. It is a breathe of fresh air for the FPS community since many other popular titles have been pretty stale as of late. The aesthetic design is great. I love how a lot of the in-game UI, instead of feeling like game UI, feels like part of your astroperator's heads-up display. And while the menu UX could use some efficiency/simplicity improvements, it is stylistically very clean and perfectly matches the style and setting of the game. 
It feels like the movement mechanics and animations have been slightly improved since earlier technical playtests that I have participated in; making transitions feel less clunky. I haven't spent enough time playing to comment on weapon balancing, but every gun that I have used so far has felt pretty good to use. 
The only disclaimer I feel like I should offer to potential buyers is that the ability to turn ANY direction can be disorienting at first and will take some getting used to. I only play using mouse and keyboard but I would bet that it might be easier to use a controller to play this game. 
The dev team does seem to be taking a fair amount of community input so I definitely recommend getting involved reporting bugs or giving suggestions in the Boundary Discord server.

This review is going to be in 3 parts. The first will be directed at people new to the series, the second at everyone, and third at existing MMBN fans. 

Before getting to that though, I'm just going to start with my opinion: yes I recommend it, but I'm a MMBN fan so of course I would say that, I want people to get this game so that Capcom could see this be popular and make a new game, so the rest of this review is just trying to be informative. 

Part 1: For New People

The Mega Man Battle Network games were a collection of action RPGs (mostly) for the GBA games. This collection and the simultaneously released Vol 2 contain all of the 6 numbered entries (all except the first two entries were split into 2 versions like Pokemon, hence the "10 games" in marketing). This collection contains the first 3, and vol. 2 contains 4-6.

The gameplay is a little difficult to describe. Combat takes place on a 6x3 grid, where the left 3x3 is where you can move around, and the right 3x3 is where your enemies can move. 5 battle chips are drawn from your deck of 30, which you select based on shared letter (think "suit" of card) and shared chip type. You battle for 9 seconds, where you can move on the grid, use your chips, and/or your (relatively weak) megabuster.  after which you can choose to return to chip selection, and repeat until the enemy is defeated.  This system is expanded upon as the game goes on and becomes increasingly nuanced and complex (the final entry supports a robust PvP meta, for example), but these basics are upheld. 

This system would later go on to inspire One Step from Eden. Unlike One Step from Eden, however, this game isn't a rougelike. There is a set story, involving Lan Hikari in the real world, who operates Mega Man.exe, his Net Navi, in the cyberworld, in their fight against viruses and a (game-dependent) terrorist organization. Generally Lan moves in the real world, finds a place for Mega Man to "jack-in" and enter either a local network or the internet. On the internet, battles come from in the form of random encounters.

The game's stories aren't really their strong point. It is mostly typical shounen fare, often hindered by awkward localization with numerous typos (particularly in BN 4). Most of the fun is derived from improving your chip folder and skills as you fight ever stronger navis. The games have a lot of mechanical depth, particularly the later entries, which lets players spend a lot time tinkering with folder set-up.

In general, 1 and 4 are considered to be the weakest games. 1 is janky in the way that first entries often are, and 4 suffers from a series of poor design decisions and a particularly atrocious translation effort. 3 and 6 are generally considered the highlights. 3 for its post-game and varied settings, and 6 for its gameplay and PvP. Playing the games in order is recommended, but if you aren't enjoying 1, you can try skipping to 6 to see if the series is for you at all. Or 3 if you only have this collection. Speaking of which, this bundle is $40 for the first 3 games, and the other is also $40, but you can get both for $60 if you get the bundle, which you probably should if you think you'll like these games.

Some tips:
1) Buster Max mode is basically a "cheat" mode that puts your base buster power to 100 and can let you breeze through the games. Keep this in mind if this is something you are interested in, even if just for speeding up grinding.
2) If you are struggling and don't want to resort to the above, try reducing the number of letter codes in your folder. Putting a bunch of powerful chips is great and all, butt if you are only getting one chip each turn, you are going to be much less effective.
3) The Rockman Exe Zone has a very helpful wiki that is well organized if you ever want to consult a resource.

Part 2: For Everyone

This collection has added online support with a (simplistic) ranked system for battling other players. Not all of the games are balanced, but 6 in particular is balanced in a way which has lead a competitive scene existing for it (and has had decent-sized following for several years now). I expect that to continue in this collection once people have gotten themselves solid collections of chips to participate in it.

Also new to the collection are the ability to gain "download chips" which were Japanese only event chips at a press of a button. Similarly, one can use "patch cards" which were Japanese-only E-reader cards which were used for a variety of things. Mega Man is also voiced in the title screen, and will have a variety of things to say depending on the circumstances when playing the game. You can look at a variety of artwork and promotion material for the games, and listen to music from the games (and see achievements linked to the Steam achievements).

Part 3: For Existing MMBN Fans

The in game changes are relatively minor. Ever game has a "buster-max" mode which lets you put your base megabuster damage to 100 if you want to just skip through some tedious parts of the games. The text has been replaced from the pixelated ones with new high resolution ones. The games are all based on the JP versions, so there isn't any cut content (well, except Botkai Crossover battles in 6 and Beast Gate content), so there is more content than the GBA Western release. You can change languages in the option menu on the same save, which can be nice for those learning Japanese and/or Chinese. There is a filter option which starts as on by default, but you can turn it off (I personally do). There are also borders you can select around the game, but there is no "no border" option for those of you who do not like it. Some bugs were patched out, and some were kept in single-player but patched out of PvP battles. Enumerating which were are beyond the scope of this review, but you can check out fan communities for detailed info if you are interested, like Rockman exe corner and Team Battle Network.

Some bugs have been introduced, however. A minor visual one involving sprites looking like they are standing on the player character is somewhat common. More seriously, the MMBN6 Virus Battler rewards currently are set to the ones from the western GBA release which is problematic, so you should change your language to Japanese when doing it until that is fixed.

Another minor annoyance is with the soundtrack currently being a mono version of it, rather than Stereo which was in the GBA games. I imagine there will be a fan patch for this in the near future. Another is that the game used Denuvo. However, Capcom usually removes it a year or two after release, if previous releases are anything to go by, so it probably won't be permanent.
